content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												An awesome experience of space exploration and exploitation that none of other 4x provided. Don't get me wrong, I've been a fan of moo/moo2 for decades and spent some hundreds of hours in gc2, and still I believe moo is the best in its genre... The thing is that stellaris is different in the most positive sense of this word. The grand strategy elements yet make you expect the depth and complexity you really want of it. The seemingly slow-paced sandbox feel of the early game is combined with the tension of getting acquainted with some nasty neighbors, and feeling the breath of those militaristic xenophobes 3 stars away from your borders makes you anxiously build military while you want to grow your planets, and science, and purge those amoebas preventing you from getting that sweet sweet gaia, and... It is something brand new in space strategy, and it is fantastic.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												It's a brilliant blend of various genres, mostly strategies/4x: Civ (4, 5, BE), Alpha Centauri, GalCiv 2 (haven't played 3), Spore (space age), Masters of Orion, Sins of a Solar Empire, and of course EU (3 and 4 particuilarly).It has extreme attention to detail, superbly intelligent design, envigorating voice acting, sound effects, artwork, narratives, and even quests/assignments!There is tremendous amount of depth and immersion, without the horrible tediousness and learning curve of many of the games amalgamated in to this masterpiece. The UI is gorgeous and fluid, incorporating obvious notes from pros and cons of prior UI methods. The tutorial is fun and actually helpful.This comes from someone who is extremely difficult to please, and tends to bounce from one game to another in an search for satisfaction - I'll be stuck on this for the next 500+ hours.My only regret is not pre-ordering the Nova or Galaxy Editions, as I was wary of being disappointed.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												So, review time. I have only played this game for 80 minutes so far, so take this as a 'first impressions' review. Starting off, it can be a little overwhelming as it is different yet also the same as most other Paradox games. At first, there is a feeling of tension as you know what will happen and you move to get yourself suited for first contact. As with any new game there is also a learning curve, but it is not very steep at all. The soundtrack is amazing and has kept me completely immersed in my space-fairing adventures. The tutorial however, while comprehensive. can be a bit annoying becuase it completely covers your list of what to do. That said the tutorial guide is quirky and can even bring out a few good chuckles. All in all from a beginners point of view, this game is great. Perhaps not a must buy for anyone unwilling to learn something new, but if you dont fall into that category then congratulations you have a potential new game in your library that can be played for hours on end!

												Have not played a whole lot of this game yet, but so far its been very fun. The game as a whole is extremely complicated to someone knew to 4X games (like me). I have never played a 4X game or grand strategy game and it was difficult to learn the ropes at first. I had to lose an empire to get the hang of it.Once I figured the game out more my second try went much better. The game feels polished, there are no glaring glitches in the game. Be warned, if you are not interested in reading this is not the game for you! Nearly all information is given in the form of text and there are not many voice overs passed the tutorial sections. You will be presented with paragraphs to read. The tutorial system is kind of sub-par in my oppinion. Nothing is highlited during the tutorials, so some times finding where the tutorial wants you to click is difficult. There is no path for the tutorial, it kind of just puts you into a regualr game and gives you information as you click on new things with some very sugjested things to do. None of them are actually required to do when the tutorial promps you.All in all I think its a great game. Its fun and entertaining, the complexity is very high, but not so high its impossible to learn from no information. It just takes a little effort.

content:

												Played for nine hours right out of the gate and overall I am highly impressed and have enjoyed myself so far. I'm new to the grand strategy genre of games and so far with the help of the excellent tutorial I've been making my way through with little trouble in grasping the overall concept and gameplay mechanics. There's a ton of customization in this game from designing and outfitting your own ships to setting up your faction. I like how you can use our solar system as your starting point complete with all the planets. Graphics are great and remind me of Sins of a Solar Empire. Game runs smooth as glass with no slowdown or stuttering that some people are experiencing (i7 920, 7970, SSD). Over the course of nine hours only had one lockup that required a reboot but with the autosave option I only had to replay about 2 min of gameplay. No regrets with this one, can't wait to play some more!

content:
Posted: March 10
												With recent updates, I had a lot fun to design ships and to manage my fleet composition towards space battles.Comparing with HOI or EU series, this game surprisingly has the best navy battle mechanism. Although decisive battle doctrine still applies to this game, you cannot win a battle just by spamming covette/torpedo boat or battleship/carrier alone. Ships can be designed to counter smaller opponents or bigger opponents, and to win a battle you will need to have a healthy mix (or even better, to have ships designed to counter ships of your enemies when your know their designs).For player who wants to design and manage a grand fleet mixed with different types of ships that designed for different purposes, this will be a game you shouldn't miss.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												Verify different from your standard 4x and obviously influenced by their other work (especially CK II).Without going into too much detail, the main difference with this vs other 4x (Master of Orion for example), is just as with your Demense in CK II, you cannot control more than x planets without suffering penalties (nothing super major, but enough that ou don't want to go over by more than 1-2.Other major difference that makes it vastly more challenging (but not necessarily more difficult) than other space 4x: Terraforming is an end game tech (hopefully it stays this way, as it alters your strategy immensely, and adds a different dimension to the game).The end result is that this game, unlike other 4x, isn't a rush to grab as many planets as possible, then go from there. It requires careful calculation of where you'll invest your resources, and requires you to be careful with what planets you colonize. Only thing I'd change is add a 4th speed to make the game even faster, but then again as with EU and CK, by the end game the amount of processing required per day slows the speed down anyway.

content:

												I have a spilt opinion for stellaris. When it was released it was pretty shi.t. Everything was fairly samey and the mid game was boring as hell to play through with the late game not being as great as hoped. But, it is way more fun in the 1.3 patch. More events, more A.I variety, more strategies. But then they put out dlc with the game not feeling finished. This game feels like an early access game but it was released as a finished one, which rubs me the wrong way. To sum it up, is it good? Yes, but it can be better. Should you buy it? If you're alright with the game not feeling entirely finished and alright with waiting for more patches. I don't regret buying the game too much. 30% out of 100. But if I knew about the state of the game before i bought it on day one then i would've waited. So far it seems like they want to continue working on the game, not sure for how long though. So if you want the game, the 1.3.1 patch is pretty fun on its own. Take that as you will.

												I'm barely into this game yet, but I like it a lot. It has the feel of Paradox's other Grand Strategy titles, but starting out with a single planet is much more laid back than starting out in most of their games. The random nature of the starting positions should keep things pretty fresh as well. I'm guilty in their other games as playing the same countries again and again, and this game isn't going to be like that. content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												Loved it so far. A bunch of my friends have really been waiting for this, and we were so hyped up for the release today. Apart from one stutter glitch, I was really surprised at how *not* buggy this game was from release. These days, it seems most games come out on release with a plethora of game breaking bugs, or a few that ruin it for a lot. But not this game. I give a full recommendation, however I will admit there is a learning curve and if you don't do your research or let the game give you the full tutorial, you will get stuck! This is not a game to be felt out without help! I jumped right into a multiplayer with my friends, and even then it was hard.A few tibits extra about the game I liked:-Music is beautiful-Graphics are pretty and nice to look at-UI is *not* disgusting, it just is not for the faint of heart.-Races are creative, well drawn, and look cool-Quite a lot of techs and facets to exploreGreat day-one gameplay for me personally. Can't wait for the Star Wars, 40K, and Mass Effect Mods. I know they're coming!

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												I'm barely into this game yet, but I like it a lot. It has the feel of Paradox's other Grand Strategy titles, but starting out with a single planet is much more laid back than starting out in most of their games. The random nature of the starting positions should keep things pretty fresh as well. I'm guilty in their other games as playing the same countries again and again, and this game isn't going to be like that. Also, knowing Paradox, this game will continue to be improved for years to come. I look forward to seeing where it goes. Highly recommended, especially if you're a fan of the developer!

												I hope to write a more in depth review once more time has be logged. Only 5.5 hours thus far but I couldn't wait to get my first peek at this wishlist game of mine. Personally, I don't think this game disappoints at all. You have to have an appreciation for Paradox games to get it and some of those still may not. Love the soundtrack and feeling of galactic proportions this game so far seems to deliver. I actually feel like a fledgling starfaring explorer wondering what my actions may reap in the future as I start to make contacts as I explore the unkown. Love this game so far Paradox. Finally something to itch my star searching craving in a grand stratedy game where the game can be real time but not feel like Im being overwhelmed from every direction. Cant wait to see how the diplomacy here works out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												Have not played a whole lot of this game yet, but so far its been very fun. The game as a whole is extremely complicated to someone knew to 4X games (like me). I have never played a 4X game or grand strategy game and it was difficult to learn the ropes at first. I had to lose an empire to get the hang of it.Once I figured the game out more my second try went much better. The game feels polished, there are no glaring glitches in the game. Be warned, if you are not interested in reading this is not the game for you! Nearly all information is given in the form of text and there are not many voice overs passed the tutorial sections. You will be presented with paragraphs to read. The tutorial system is kind of sub-par in my oppinion. Nothing is highlited during the tutorials, so some times finding where the tutorial wants you to click is difficult. There is no path for the tutorial, it kind of just puts you into a regualr game and gives you information as you click on new things with some very sugjested things to do. None of them are actually required to do when the tutorial promps you.All in all I think its a great game. Its fun and entertaining, the complexity is very high, but not so high its impossible to learn from no information. It just takes a little effort.

												Fabulous game, I have already sunk 6 hours into this game and will probably play it every day for, at least, another month. I've been waiting for this game for months, and I finally have it. :)Overall, it is the perfect mix of 4x and grand strategy. People have criticized the games shortcoming and bugs *cough* *cough* IGN, but just look at the support this game has.On day 1, I and many others experienced a stuttering bug. Where everything stuttered and made the game nearly unplayable. Now, on day 2, that has been fixed in a hotfix patch. The devs have even stated, in their launch stream, that they intend to release DLC adding what players think is the weakest part of the game.These are truly great devs. They have continued to support CK2 and EU4, and will do the same for Stellaris. This game is great now, but with Paradox's support over the years it could be a masterpiece.Overall, this game is a must buy.

												this is everything i had expected, the best game released in a very long time. best space x4 since distant worlds, and not only that its best grand strategy, its merging of 2 genres works well, and it finally fixes the broken politics of past space x4 games and makes politics finally work in these type of games.im not entirely sure if it totally beats distant worlds yet..... its very very close, so close that i cant even say which is best. the population unit thing isnt as much as a issue as i even imagined it would be, they pulled that bit off well. game brings so many new things to the space x4 genre ....but the thing is..... we all know this game isnt even finished yet!we all know it will have 200 more expansions, which all will add EVEN MORE features and new ideas to the game. currently we can view the game in a basic form, its basic form is so awesome it maybe better than distant worlds universe...... but with the 200 extra exansions or so, this game will be so FAAAAR beyond distant worlds that there would be no comparing.i cant even imagine how much this will improve in future editions!and that makes it even more exciting.a must buy, totally excelent game, best release in very long time, really a must own for your library!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												This game is like a better Civ 3. It's like a better Endless Space (If you prefer RTS opposed to turn-based.)   It's one of the best Scifi space Rts's I've ever played. It could use a little extra polish in the form of optimization and clearing out a few bugs. When Vermintide released, it was VERY poorly optimized. Hell, when Ark came out (admittedly it was in EA for a long time) It needed weeks before it was playable on most machines.Stellaris is a game that's going to eat away every hour of spare time I have when I'm not working. (Please don't take my working hours too. I need to eat something more than ramen every once in a while.)If there is DLC it's almost instantly going to be a buy. An expansion? Insta buy. This game is amazing and feature-full. There's a lot of 'winks' / 'hat tilts' / 'easter-eggs' in the events, but they're not blatant like Borderlands games. It's not full of memes, but if you look carefully, you'll get what's going on.There's soooo many things I want to talk about event-wise, but I think all the fun is in finding them for yourself.The only thing I CAN'T recommend right now is Iron Man Mode. It saves constantly and really slows down the pace of things. The constant saving with the (eventual) optimization issues that come into play late-game, make it a bit rough at times.But with that said, this is a 10/10.This is Scifi RTS 4x perfected. Well done devs.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												So, I’m liking the game but I am unsure if it is my love for this style of game or the game itself I’m loving.  I can say I feel there were a few missed opportunities.  I’m a huge fan of CK2 and Imperium Galactica 2 (oh how I was hoping for a worthy successor).  I am enjoying the game thought so please don’t be discouraged.  Paradox has a record of improving games with mods/patches/DLC and stand by their titles.  So I’m not overly worried.Stellaris offers what many of us have been missing in that it is real time 4x space strategy game.  Finally no more “end turn” right?  Freely customizable race, easy modding, and a nice arrangement of traits/characteristics allow for replay ability.  Keep an eye out for mods in workshop though as they will probably be able to take the vanilla game further in its current state.Diplomacy could use some work.  Coming from an experience like CK2 where there is such a detailed level of advisors, intrigue, relationships, etc.… you will be underwhelmed by the diplomacy.  Like no joke, there’s not much to it…  Planets…  So I am not sure if I am for or against this rather dated style of planet/colony management.  It reminds me of Master of Orion where planets have tiles which can be modified to produce a resource based off the building.  It works for the game so I have no real complaints on it, just seems like an old mechanic that we have seen before.  Something I’m not too fond of is the planet control system and how your kind a forced to give up control of your systems to a governor after you a mass a few colonies.  I suppose if there was more interaction or even the feeling that I was handing over my territory to someone of value it wouldn’t be so bad.  However, it feels quite static.  Made me miss CK2 and long for those intriguing back stabbing plots to break away or declare independence from my rule.  There is little you can do to control how you want your sectors run and leaders again are quite static.  Not to mention limited in availability.  Don’t expect to have scientist, generals, admirals, and leaders everywhere or even in all the above areas.So combat is indeed 4x, but doesn’t really feel like it.  More or less move one fleet onto an enemy fleet and they swarm around firing.  No direct player control.  Again, not a complaint, it works.  And the UI window on battles during and after offers more details to help redesign your ships versus CK2 UI.  Sadly I feel the 4x component is wasted in this though…Overall the game is very vanilla, like not even vanilla bean, or vanilla with sprinkles….it’s just vanilla.  However, mods and time will tell if Paradox adds to it and brings us the enjoyment we have seen in other titles (CK2) (I mention CK2 because I’d so die happy for a CK2 in space type game).  I am enjoying it though and have already logged many hours since its release here.  I will leave you with this thought…  Recall back to the early days of CK2 and how it was at first launch, or even some other titles…  I’m just looking towards the future and ready to reach for my pocket book for the plethora of DLC to come.  :)

content:
Posted: January 17
												A very nice game with many fun aspects. I recommend trying different mods from the community as that spices up the game dramatically. I personally play with 5-10 different ones that fixes smaller issues or adding extra layers to the game. Avoid the Planetoids DLC as it doesnt really affect the overall-gameplay and save the money for something else. It mainly brings in a different race, which there are quite a few of anyway (and you can make your own aswell).The multiplayer element is really cool aswell and I like how easy it is to join the game even though you havent been there from the beginning. "Wanna join? No worries, you can just take over one of the AI." The main problem is being unable to synchronise mods in some way or atleast see which one is missing from the hosts own game. I dont think its unfair as the mods deviate from the original game design but when its such a nice sandbox game, why not help the community abit in making the game "their own". It isnt a unique flaw as it is the same with Total War: Warhammer.For gamers that love to spend time building an empire while still being able to command fleets of battleships, this game is a good choice.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												So far very good.  Take a classic space colinization and make many unique twists regarding UI, gameplay, and strategy.  Love the human element of leaders that get reelected and die.  A bit overwhelming at first as usually these games are, but find it rather straight forwards once you get the hang of it.  Busy restarting worlds after about an hour each time, as I learn more.  Addictive already.If you want a quick mod, go into the C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\steamapps\common\Stellaris\common\traits\00_species_traitsfile.  Change one of the traits like intelligent to cost like -20 instead of 2.  Now you can start a super race, with some extra power to counter the learning curve.  There is no easy level, just normal.  So don't feel wrong to cheat a little.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												So, review time. I have only played this game for 80 minutes so far, so take this as a 'first impressions' review. Starting off, it can be a little overwhelming as it is different yet also the same as most other Paradox games. At first, there is a feeling of tension as you know what will happen and you move to get yourself suited for first contact. As with any new game there is also a learning curve, but it is not very steep at all. The soundtrack is amazing and has kept me completely immersed in my space-fairing adventures. The tutorial however, while comprehensive. can be a bit annoying becuase it completely covers your list of what to do. That said the tutorial guide is quirky and can even bring out a few good chuckles. All in all from a beginners point of view, this game is great. Perhaps not a must buy for anyone unwilling to learn something new, but if you dont fall into that category then congratulations you have a potential new game in your library that can be played for hours on end!

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												Probably one of the most interesting and fun games I've played. And I've barely gotten to mid-game if that even. So many possibilities for how you can play so I just keep restarting to try things out. Sure there are a few buggy things here and there, and definitely a number of things where you go "boy I wish this was a feature" but if you look at any other Paradox game (I've only played V2 and CK2 well after they were released) there should be a ton of DLC to add even more. Only major downside is that the UI gets kinda small on larger screens. My resolution is at 2160x1440 and I have to get pretty close to see it super well. But this just seems to be a Paradox issue. Not game breaking, but more of a quality of life problem.I'd put it more complete than Civ 5 was at release, with as much or even potential to get better later.9/10 definitely get it if you like 4X or space.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												Make no mistake this is a continuation of Europa Universalis in it's core gameplay. What's changed is: - the decor has become magnificent. Instead of stinky medieval empires, you control and encounter, or deal with and suffer from space age stuff. (I took a risk of 22% to explore a gas giant. I ended up setting of a chain reaction that killed off the entire indegenious species that lived in those clouds... whoops).- EU4 armies are now fully configurable corvettes, destroyers, cruisers and battleships, with modules, you can configure under 3 researchable tech trees. - so much other stuff... Anyway, there are still some problems with diplomacy, and some imbalance in weapons... But for the first time, the game is moddable! So modders can help developp the game further.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												I have played this game 19 of the 50 hours since release. I am often disappointed with games at start and I like games that feel more complete and Paradox are notoriously bad at that, making games that seem more like good ideas until a couple of DLCs in. This game is not like that.I think Stellaris might be the best game that I've played. All the 4 X:s of eXploration, eXpansion, eXploitation, and eXtermination are fun. It got character and it got style, the small speeches by alien (and human) empires are well-written and colourful, that alien empires insult you if they find what you're doing bad is amusing and the AI behaves logically.One bad thing. The game is buggy. This will improve soon, since Paradox are good at putting out patches in good time.Apart from that I have yet to find faults. 10/10. Possibly the best game I've ever played.

												For folks looking for space exploration and empire builders, the 4X crowd, this is your holy grail.  Early game focuses on exploration, charting, and colonization with strong barriers blocking the normal early-game colony rush.  Science and discovery is as important as raw resource might in this phase and adds endless charm and uniqueness to each game.Mid game transitions into one of diplomacy and early warfare as you and your neighbors establish a pecking order.  Exploration still occurs but the sites are dwindling by this point.Late game moves into vast empires and federations staking claims and rearranging neighborhoods all over slights big and small.Add to this late game crises (extra-dimensional invaders for example), relic ancient empires vastly beyond your starting capacity, nascent and emerging low-tech races, and a rewarding tech system you have a game that breathes fun and freshness in every play through.Personally, this is what I've been waiting for nearly 20 years.It was worth the wait.  And even more so now with the post-release improvements!

EXPANSIONS, the leviathans expansion brings something new to the End game and I highly recommend it for anyone looking for some wonderful end game content. Regarding the race packs, I bought them, but they are hardly needed, there are just as well made mods that bring as much to the game as the race packs. Still a YES

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
												Its good. Its actually better than good. 4X Space strategy game similar to Endless Space and Master of Orion. Huge galaxies up to 1000 systems each. You can have a small number of core systems (4-5) that you need to micromanage throughout the game, but beyond that you need to allocate systems into sectors, under the control of governors. Within a sector all the building is automated, except for warships. You can generally tell a sector to specialise in collecting energy (creds), minerals, research or defence. You can also set empire policies and sector policies that influence how fast your race drifts from the original colonists of your homeworld. This is where the game shines. They automate the micromanagement of individual population units, but you still have to worry non-stop about the politics of your Empire. For example, I uplifted some random animal species and made them intelligent voting members of the Empire. Sects within the Empire popped up centered around the spiritualism of uplifting species, and the animals I uplifted didnt have time to adapt culturally so the became a collectivist entity. One generation later and I have 2 revolts within my Empire happening while I am fighting a war against a robot hive mind. Meanwhile my open migration policy for the last 100 years has caused another sector of my empire to relate more to the bird people Empire than to the humans from Terra, and one system breaks away wanting to be part of an independent protectorate within the Empire. Its well worth checking out. You wont get the cinematic battles of Endless Space, but it is absolutely riveting to play through this game.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												This was my last game:Fueled by a strong economy and free migration policies, the Democratic Union of Humans (DUH) was the pre-eminent empire that liberated planets from the cruel and tyrranical rule of despotic rulers across the galaxy.  As other empires found that peace was better than war, they established open migration treaties to ensure harmony and cooperation between the empires.  Unfortunately, DUH attracted most of the unwanted populations from other empires and quickly became saddled with heavy social welfare programs to keep everyone happy.  Soon thereafter, the programs proved too expensive to sustain leaving DUH with unhappy and unproductive planets.  The failure cascade accelerated with the failing economy as DUH found it unable to support its military to protect its borders from opportunistic empires and quell internal rebellions for independence.  Sadly, the DUH experiment failed and the very populations that were unhappy with the freedoms they enjoyed found themselves conquered and enslaved... But at least they were happier in the end!  Or purged...Next game I am getting the collectivist trait.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26
												This is game I should like, instead it has become an excersize in frustration.Want an example ?Google Stellaris fleet sizes, or fleet caps. See the answers experts give to questions about fleet sizes. Usually it goes along the lines of I have 24k in my fleet, they never actually answer the posters question and those that try too leave out vital information. So most players, dont actually know how this game works, they just manage to some how stumble on a formula that works. You see the answer to that question pretty much reveals the games flaws. Fleet caps are a combination of space station upgrades, large populations and research. Where as research goes faster when you only have a small population. So the larger your population gets, the slower you research is and the larger your fleet becomes. From then on you fall behind and end up losing to an empire with only 3 planets to its name. So you have to gather research resources to boost your research as your empire expands, this means expanding slowly, letting your population on planets grow before settling new ones and using your influence to build frontier out posts in resource rich areas. These require energy and energy is the one thing that is in short supply. So you have to balance expansion, with research with the need to build mines and research out posts in order to keep your empire growing and competative. That is why nobody ever answers that question properly. Sounds like I just did right, well kind of.You see, whilst your happy with your 2000 strength fleet, that 3 planet AI turns up with a 16,000 strength fleet that it really should not have because you now know how that fleet cap is worked out now and you can see from the diplomacy screen that his tech level is not any higher than yours, so his fleet should at best be comparable to yours. So you know beyond any doubt that the AI cheats like crazy and whilst your limited by these rules, it is not.Next we come to diplomacy, an AI that loves you to bits makes you its rival, which gives you an instant -100 rep with that AI. All the bonuses recieved before that gave it a +93 rep, meaning it loved you to bit, yet sees you as its enemy. It attacks you, you beat it. You conquer all its planets, destroy all its mines and out posts and end up drawn in a war because its ally beat your ally. Even though you pretty much wiped him out. After the war, a truce is declared and your ally invites this AI in to your Federation, before the flames of war have even gone out, this AI is now your best friend and the truce setting is still clearly visible on the AI that is now your ally. Meaning that uneasy post war peace is still uneasy as it joins your federation and becomes your bestie.These 2 examples reveal what is wrong with this game, it is less of game you play and more of a system you learn and then exploit. It makes very little sense because the game mechanics are not there to make game play, they are to stop one AI from steam rolling the entire galaxy. You see, if they just let an AI grow and linked research to empire size as most games do, then the biggest AI would always win. So instead they make the smallest AI research things faster, so they catch up, grow in size, suddenly their research slows down and they become an out dated large empire too. Mean while the tiny Mr Nobody empire with only 3 planets has quietly researched everything and is now a super power that nobody can beat. That is whats wrong with this game, the mechanics make no sense so you end up playing the system, not the game. In infact, I am absolutely certain the lead designer spends his nights licking magic mushrooms in some damp English field someplace. If you like spending 70 hours saying WTF, I strongly recommend this game, but if you dont, go and by Galactic Civ 3 instead. At least that makes sense. And remember the reason people tend not to answer questions properly about this game is because they dont actually know how it works either.  Just ask them for a full answer and you see what I mean.Just to ram that point home, look at the Global Achievements for this game, only 19% of those who buy it manage to settle a planet. In game thats pretty much about settling planets, that means 81% of those who buy it dont even get started in this game.

Posted: May 9, 2016
												This is one of the first games I have pre-ordered, I was betting on the fact that since Paradox was making this game (which also used the new ClausWitz engine) that Stellaris would be a great game... and it is. The UI is smart and easy to read/understand, the Advisor gives useful tips while not making you feel like a complete idiot for not understanding. Like all Paradox games this is not the easiest game to get into, its complexity is a beauty of its own just like in CK2 and EU4 but it has its own feel to it- it takes a completely different approach into Real Time Grand Strategy Games.Great Game, 10/10 would recomend to everyone who enjoys/wants to start playing a Grand Strategy game. Really decent price too considering the content/gameplay you will get out of it- especially with all the mod which will be created some time in the near future

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
Product received for free
												So I'm going to start out by saying I've never played Europa Universalis 4 or any other EU game but I'm in love with the civilization series. Now, I know there's not much of a correlation between civ and EU but let's talk about Stellaris. Stellaris gives me that adventurous feel of being able to make decisions and struggle to make other nations around me do what I want them to do. That's the strength in Stellaris. How accessible is the game to a beginner? I'd say it's accessible enough that you will learn new things every time you play through it and learn what techs do what and what strategies work and what don't. The technologies are learned through a little bit of RNG with some weights to make sure you eventually get the important stuff (like a colony ship etc). The game is chalk full of hilarious scientific arguements and references to a ton of stuff. One of my favorites is the teapot behind the sun anamoly, 'cuz it's just funny to think about.Anyway is the game worth the price? Hell yes. Also yay for Mod Support - that'll add some value to the game for sure.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												This is the best 4x I have ever played. I got it today and I have been playing it nonstop since I downloaded it. I highly recomend it. It combines my favorites aspects of both grand strategy and 4x. The graphics and user interface is incredible. It is the most accessible paradox game I have ever played and I have played all of paradox's grand strategy games. The lack of a tech tree makes gameplay more emergent and interesting. So many aspects combine to make it impossible for any two campaigns to be the same. The early game is an exciting colonization race. The midgame smoothly transitions from a more 4x style gameplay to one the is more similar to eu4. There are many novel ideas. If you want to see streams of stellaris being played, look at the blorg streams and the london multiplayer streams on twitch by ParadoxInteractive. I would give this game 10/10.

content:
Posted: October 22, 2016
												Stellaris will be a good game someday. But as it is, most of the fun comes from modders adding content to what is on its own really just the framework for a much better game waiting to be created. I imagine as the years pass and Paradox, being as DLC happy as they are, release more and more updates and expansions we will eventually see Stellaris blossom into a solid 4X game to rival even the best on the market. But for now it's a glorified sandbox for modders to play in. It reminds me a lot of Paradox's Crusader Kings 2 in this regard, which was also a game that was merely okay upon launch and didn't really come into it's own until many expansions later.So if you don't mind browsing the workshop to bring out the games potential, certainly pick it up. And then put it away and check back in a few years when Paradox has totally overhauled it via expansion packs and DLC.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												Before I get into the review I will simply say this, If you like Civilization, you will like this. Buy it.Words can not describe how much fun this game is. This is probably going to be my first 1000 hour game. On to the review.Also I want to mention that I never found the interface to be 'Bad' or 'complicated' I learned it after 2 games and never had any issues.This game is a gem in the space strategy genre and will only improve as mods continue to pour in.A great mix between grand strategy, 4x, and a little bit of CIV5 sprinkled on top.I started the game expecting this to be super complicated and hard to learn (and I can see how it could be for novice strategy players perhaps) Luckily this game has a good tutorial.The 'Tutorial' is a little A.I. Assistant that is well voiced and even a little funny. He will describe the process of running an empire down to the little details, and after only 2 shortish games I was ready to play with limited help, and on the third game I turned the tips off. I was constantly immersed in this massive (if you choose it to be) galaxy, in which I interacted with species ranging to Xenophobic Zealot snapping turtle people, to Democratic Crusader parrot people who detest dictators . In my second game I was surrounded on my left and right by xenophobic spiritualists who wanted nothing more than to destroy my military republic, luckily I used a preemptive strike to vassalize the empire to my east, and with our combined forces I vassalized the empire to the west becoming the most powerful species in only an hour and a half of gameplay!Gameplay mechanics:On your planets you have to build on the various tiles of land masses. These can range from mining stations to collect valuable minerals, to power plants to collect the all important energy.In order to build and maintain a large fleet you need to have a large amount of minerals and energy coming in or you will find yourself with no money to spend on planet development. You also need to balance out the research buildings to advance your empires technology level.You can create custom ships by picking different modules, such as a module with 4 small guns or a module with one big gun. Ships in your navy range from corvettes to massive battleships.You can choose to equip your ship with tons of armor, or high powered shields, Lasers, Missiles, ECT.Ship combat is fairly average at worst. Reminds me a bit of RISK. With your fleet strength measured in a number over their heads.Sometimes if you have very good missile defense systems on your ships and fight an enemy fleet that only uses missiles you can absolutely tear them a new one without any losses, but the strategy does not really get much deeper.Planet Combat:Planet invasions are pretty simple. You can build an army ranging from simple soldiers to freaking Xenomorphs (not kidding thats what they are called in game). Which is pretty cool. You orbitally bombard the planet to weaken their defenses and then land your troops, if you have a better army you win and control the planet. Easy.There is so much in this game I can hardly describe it all, so I will get on to the bad stuff-Game runs poorly on my computer late gameMy computer is not a beast but with an i3-4160 and an AMD R9 270x, that should be more than enough for this game which leads to my next problem--NO GRAPHICS OPTIONSBesides multisampling and resolution there are no graphics settings in any menus. You can do some stuff in the command menu in game, but it should be in the options.-Combat is pretty meh. Planet invasions are pretty lame especially with the cool armies you can make.You just watch a small icon of your army land on a picture of a planet. A little dissapointing after I started getting cool stuff like Xenomorphs and Gene Warrior armies (Basically Spartan Super soldiers). Imagine Spartans riding Xenomorphs into battle who wouldnt want to see that??Overall I rate this game a good 8.5/10 I very much look forward to expanded content and some sweet mods.P.S. You can change alliance names and federation names by clicking the icon in the lower right hand corner :)

												Very good, just the way a 4x game should be. The developers roadmap forward looks great, and will most likely take care of most of my issues with the game. these are:1. after starting and playing around i realise that the amounts of large random events at start are not so many, maybe 3-4 big ones and a few smaller coupled to the first space-living creatures.  Needs to be improved2. lack of midgame random events.3. The AI is as usual not so good in 4x games 4. The diplomacy is weak in many areas.The reasonable simplistic warfare and dependancy on sectors is promising for the biggest weakness in all 4x games, the ai. Therefore tha ai should be easier to fix.Still its a fun game and i spend alot of time in it. Not like gal. civ 3, which was a big dissapointment.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												I have played many strategy games in my time. And if there was ever a well made space strategy, grand strategy, where almost ANYTHING can happen. This would be it. And I totally reccomend this game to anyone who loves Sci-Fi and Strategy. This game is Civ meets Sins Of A Solar Empire and an amazing part is that the developer knows how amazing their game is so they are still constructing things tweaking things and making it better with stellar (pun intended) content.There are problems when it comes to giant scenarios or large fleet battles. Ship battles get very cluttered and infantry batles don't make sense, especially if you have the clear advantage and still manage to lose the battle.Sometimes the game lags drastically especially in the large maps. I definitly reccomend having a high-mid grade PC build just to get the best out of the game.But all in all this game is complex underneath and it surprises me almost every time. Throw mods in the mix and things go to♥♥♥♥♥♥real quick.Fun game to pass time or to dive into. I tottally reccomend it

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												This is a fun, relaxing game... until an intergalactic bug race decides to invade and take over your galaxy.  You ally with a Stagnant Acendancy to defeat the invasion, discecting the Queen bug to learn their secrets.  By the time the bug threat is dealt with, a different ancient powerful race awakens and decides it doesn't like your face, your ascendant ally, or anyone else who doesn't bow down to their religion.  You fight the good fight, in the face of overwhelming odds, but in the end your fleet is descimated and your empire falls to religious nutjobs who look like Toad from Super Mario Bros.Time to start a new empire, with more of a fleet focus.Definitely a good time sink, you can micromanage your empire, or divide it up into sectors for less oversight.  Late game research can get tedious, but amassing a +100K fleet and dominating your enemies sure feels good.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												I cautiously recommend it. It's a good game, but it has some features that people might not like.The negatives:Highly depends on RNG. I do not usually call it a negative, but the only events that matter have negative influence on the wellbeing of your empire: if you are not prepared, it's a game over. As these particular events - yes, I'm talking about crisises - happen in late game, all your progress becomes nullified, which sometimes can be rather annoying. Customisation is wast, yet is restricted. You have to choose the presents, not the bonuses directly, which in my opinion could push the customisation to it's glorious limits.Wars are not great. You can't control directly your fleet. Conquering the planes is a redundant mini-game that slows you down - simply because you use soldiers only when you have won all the space battles and is bombing the plants' fortification - taking them without bombing is 75 times harder for armies.AI is weird, just like in your usual strategy game of this genre.Yes, this is a positive review. The game itself is good and easily enjoyable. It has something that was making you to make that 'one more turn' in Civilization games.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												So, this game is probably not for everyone, but I'm really enjoying it.Do you like other Paradox games where the goal is...well, whatever you want, since there is no win scenario? Then you'll likely like this (though you actually CAN win this one).  If you don't? Well...You build a galactic empire, starting from a single planet. You encounter other races, you can "uplift" some, or infiltrate some technologically inferior ones to take over, etc. There are so many options, so many ways to grow, that there are many different decisions you can make.However, the game can bog down once you get fairly in and have completely mapped your area. At that point, you might have to start conquering whatever you can around you to keep expanding. That can get difficult and boring, but it's Paradox, so if you like EU or CK, you're probably used to that by now.  (And, in my experience, this is worse the bigger the map.  Try with the smaller maps first!)

content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
												I *COULD* give a long, serious review, but that isn't how we do it.I will tell you instead, the story of the Last Pond, and how the grand empire got slaughtered from the inside. More specifically, the Turtle people, and their Grand Admiral: GroxThe Rivians were a peaceful race on a small moon, in the early space age.One day, they launched a space ship, and found many more advanced travelers of the stars.Along their borders, were the Ducks. The ducks took over anyone that was a♥♥♥♥♥♥to them, leading them to take over half the galaxy. The Rivians were all like "Yo bois, don't kill us, we wanna be ur bois!" The Ducks didn't take them seriously, and waltzed over another nation, much bigger than them. The Ducks made their biggest mistake: Giving the primitaves all their research. When Grox was born, the Ducks had taken over almost all of the galaxy. The Rivians were quietly building warships from their two planets in the romote corner of the galaxy, unable to expand because of the Duck borders. The ducks disregarded the Rivians, and ♥♥♥♥ed off to kill all the bigger guys. But what the ducks didn't know, was that the small little empire had 2x the military power in those two systems.The Ducks had started to prepare to kill off the North-Easterners, the last of the challenges, excluding the 4 fallen empires. ...Or so they thought. The Rivians needed people to lead their grand navy, and Grox outpreformed everyjuan else.He led the grand battlefleet, and they declared war on the Ducks.The ducks said "What? This tiny little nation declared war on us? Send some troops over there to Roflstomp them." They then checked the Power score, and said "Wait... What the ♥♥♥♥?" They watched as the Duck army jumped over, slowly, to the other side of the galaxy. At this point, the Rivians were Dunking on all the planets on that side of the Galaxy. The great battle commenced. After an epic battle between the brightest of the Ducks, and Grox.Grox killed all of them.He killed the millions of Ducks on those battleships, cruisers, destroyers, and even a few corvettes.He escaped with barely 10k Power Score. A fallen empire decided "Lol you know what would be funny? If we killed these dux while they rebuilt their navy."The white peace was offered for a few worlds near the Rivian Homeworld.The ducks barely held the fallen empire back, as they won, and gathered the technology.... The Rivians came back. Even more developed, even more built up.The ducks came to the defense, against an 110 year old Grox (Rivians had super life perk).The ducks put up a valiant defense, but in the end, got steamrolled by Grox.The Rivians took land, allied with every empire left, all the tiny ones the Ducks forgot, all the Northeasterners. They all came in, and stomped the Final Pond. The ducks held their core worlds valiantly, but in the end, they were wiped out.Unfortunately, the duck leader was a dumbass and put on Ironman for his first game.ffs Stupid AI-Enhancement mods.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												Paradox has done it again with an excellent Grand Strategy game.  As usual I have a video review here: 


YouTube™ Video: Stellaris Review by Thorili 

			Views: 171		

			This game has just about everything you could want; exploration, diplomacy, war, trade; and all in SPACE! The beginning of the game is very much exploration and expansion, how long this lasts depends...		

This game has just about everything you could want; exploration, diplomacy, war, trade; and all in SPACE!The beginning of the game is very much exploration and expansion, how long this lasts depends on how many other civilizations you start with.  Once you start meeting them the mid game starts and you need to decide if you are going to become bigger through diplomacy or war.  And then once you think you are powerful to take on the fallen empires (once galaxy rulers) even greater threats appear.Overall this is an absolutely amazing game and I recommend it to all that are interested in the strategy genre.  In fact it is probably the best game to get into Paradox's Grand Strategy games as the exploration and expansion ease you into the diplomacy and war.This is just single player.  Multiplayer I'd have to say is the best of any Paradox game I have played.  No desync issues, just slowing of the game in major battles.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												Very good Paradox game for Grand Strategy Starters. Graphics are nice but could be better, thank God for the great Modding Community. Game runs pretty smooth up to 800 Stars and starts to lag a little bit in the endgame (hope there will be some improvements made). The only negative thing i have to say about Stellaris are the little War-Options you are given. There are only three (Cede/Liberate Planet, Vassalize (Protektorate if you are really advanced in comparison to your enemy)) which makes no sense in a huge Galaxy with multiple different Species, thank God for the great Modding Community... again. After all i have played, I really recommend this game. Vanilla is great and with mods it becomes awesome.Notebook I play on: I7 2,6GHz, 16GB DDR4, GTX 960MMods I can recommend: Total Conversion with "Fight for Universe - Infinite Legacy" improves Game overall but not the war demands. also check out "Expended War Demands", "Beautiful Battles" and much more

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												I have 50 hours into this game. With respect to grand strategy, It is one of the best games I have ever played. As far as tactical battle, the game is merely cinema with a rpg element. If you are looking for a great tactical game, try XCOMM 2 instead. If you are looking for a well conceived strategy game, you can't do better than Stellaris.I have started the game over multiple times. Every start is very unique due to a multitude of parameters, quests, and research randomness. It definitely lends itself to replayability. To the developer that came up with the system of dual research (three scientists in the lab as well as science ships in space), I tip my hat to your brilliance. For you grand strategy geeks, those of you that embrace a stiff learning curve, this is a "must have" game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
												I have to say, i ♥♥♥♥ing love this game, though admittedly my basis here will be greatly influenced by the fact that i play with a lot of mods, which isnt neccesarily a bad thing, but some systems like for example Sectors, i just dont have experience with because i just dont use them due to mods. I was actually pretty apprehensive about buying the game, and who can blame me? Look at other paradox games like CK2 and try and tell me those are great easy to jump into games. I decided to buy the game after watching a few episodes of the Blorg playthrough (Resistance is impolite). They have on youtube. Its a great way to get an idea of how the game progresses from the beginning onwards. The game starts with you in a single system, as a species of myriad origin, having just unlocked your first FTL method. These can be Warp, slow but unrestricted, Hyperlanes, fast but restricted, and Wormholes, extremely fast and with decent range, but has a minor annoyance of having to build wormhole stations. You start with a few corvettes and a science ship along with a minor income level for minerals and energy credits and a small amount of researching ability and the game progresses from there. Customizability is fabulous, Design bird people that hate everyone who's alien and are willing to defend their lands with military might. Or design these people as a peaceful theocracy who build federations and grand alliances to protect themselves through allies.(More on this later) I thoroughly enjoy this aspect of the game and its made replayability fun, atleast for me.Gameplay is mostly managing cities, your people and to a lesser extent your policies, You also have chances to get rare technologies which can be incredibly strong or miraculously mediocre. Thankfully the vast majority of all technologies are well worth researching, Lasers especially are a joy to behold in battles watching huge swathes of ships cut an explosive path through opposing fleets is a joy to see. But you will spend most your time managing your respective leaders of your civ, and depending on your goverment type, elections. I personally due to no sectors spend a bit more time micromanaging my cities, as once you get more than 10+ planets it really is something you are just doing ALL the time, and other things like wars are just distractions from this. But thats how i prefer these games.Politics to be frank for me, were a little dissapointing. the Trust system, atleast for me never really held any meaning for me because i tend to play extremely aggressive empires. nobody ever ends up trusting me in the game(NOBODY) and im generally in a situation where its Me versus the world. But again that is just how i play, for a more peaceful player the systems probably fine, i just dont have that experience.Steam workshop support is fabulous for the longevity of the game, as mods for lots of different things, from empire colors to Flag emblems and beyond are made for the game. Also the glorious Exterminatus from the WH40k universe can be brought in. Sign the death warrant of an entire world, and consign a billlion souls to oblivion. Its awesome and i cant wait to check every few days to see what new upcoming idea modders have come up with. Its great and i can honestly say i cant imagine the game without this as it allows for so much silly♥♥♥♥♥♥to be in Stellaris as well as more serious and respectable mods.Stellaris's greatest qualities in my opinion are its Customizability, both in game for various empires, as custom made ones are allowed, and in the Workshop support to modify the rules and boundaries of the game. The battles are enjoyable but really its a hand off affair, which can be good or bad depending on your point of view. Overall if your new to Grand Strategy i think this would be a great way to enter it, but if your into more in-depth games, like CK2, i might suggest skipping it. For most people though i think Stellaris is worth its purchase price, However if you are really on the fence for the game id suggest waiting for a sale. Paradox usually have great sales on steam and it would be an absolute steal if you got it for 20$. Id rate it 8/8 Gr8 B8 M8

content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
												"Worthy of the hype." - Me, just now. I was sceptical of Stellaris. I've tried other 4x games and few of them hit the spot. But Stellaris had me from the start. I think the visuals help - there's not a hexagon in sight! The richness of the scifi is great too - I could roll-play a book I'm reading (Pandoras Star, Peter F Hamilton) and it's reminiscent enough of other SciFi - Ian Banks, Stephen Baxter and so on that I feel like those stories could be taking place in the Stellaris' Universe. It's a slow-paced game but it's not turn based - you can control the speed at which the un-paused game passes so if nothing interesting is happening till you build your next Colony Ship (for example) then you can speed things up - so slow-paced but not boring in the way I found Gal Civ 3 for example. Watch a Let's Play, then get the Galaxy Edition (cdkeys gave the best deal at time of writing) to also enjoy a novel, sound track and other goodies.Top tip - for your first game I'd recommend playing against only minor races till you learn the ropes.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												This has very quickly become my favorite 4x of all time. Most know how 4x works, so I'll just highlight what puts this on top for me. The only game that comes close to giving you that feeling of a immersive story in the 4x genre is Civ5 and that's partly down to the historical familiarity; this game achieves that without it and arguably better. They really have made the eXplore side of the game very intriguing, simply sending out a science vessal (scout) to each and every system you can, sounds labourious but it has you hanging with speculation and excitement. The diplomacy side of the game is unparrelled in the space 4x and it really is a welcome level of complexity brought in from their experience with their Europa series. I didn't think I'd like the realtime aspect as much as I do but it really fits well with this game, and I'm really looking forward to trying this out multiplayer because of it. Paradox being Paradox, we know their will be a wealth of DLC, and as much as many may hate that aspect, I'm personally really looking forward to it becuase there is so much growth potential in an already content rich game. If you love the 4x genre, you'll love this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												This was my last game:Fueled by a strong economy and free migration policies, the Democratic Union of Humans (DUH) was the pre-eminent empire that liberated planets from the cruel and tyrranical rule of despotic rulers across the galaxy.  As other empires found that peace was better than war, they established open migration treaties to ensure harmony and cooperation between the empires.  Unfortunately, DUH attracted most of the unwanted populations from other empires and quickly became saddled with heavy social welfare programs to keep everyone happy.  Soon thereafter, the programs proved too expensive to sustain leaving DUH with unhappy and unproductive planets.  The failure cascade accelerated with the failing economy as DUH found it unable to support its military to protect its borders from opportunistic empires and quell internal rebellions for independence.  Sadly, the DUH experiment failed and the very populations that were unhappy with the freedoms they enjoyed found themselves conquered and enslaved... But at least they were happier in the end!  Or purged...Next game I am getting the collectivist trait.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												For folks looking for space exploration and empire builders, the 4X crowd, this is your holy grail.  Early game focuses on exploration, charting, and colonization with strong barriers blocking the normal early-game colony rush.  Science and discovery is as important as raw resource might in this phase and adds endless charm and uniqueness to each game.Mid game transitions into one of diplomacy and early warfare as you and your neighbors establish a pecking order.  Exploration still occurs but the sites are dwindling by this point.Late game moves into vast empires and federations staking claims and rearranging neighborhoods all over slights big and small.Add to this late game crises (extra-dimensional invaders for example), relic ancient empires vastly beyond your starting capacity, nascent and emerging low-tech races, and a rewarding tech system you have a game that breathes fun and freshness in every play through.Personally, this is what I've been waiting for nearly 20 years.It was worth the wait.  And even more so now with the post-release improvements!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
												Its good. Its actually better than good. 4X Space strategy game similar to Endless Space and Master of Orion. Huge galaxies up to 1000 systems each. You can have a small number of core systems (4-5) that you need to micromanage throughout the game, but beyond that you need to allocate systems into sectors, under the control of governors. Within a sector all the building is automated, except for warships. You can generally tell a sector to specialise in collecting energy (creds), minerals, research or defence. You can also set empire policies and sector policies that influence how fast your race drifts from the original colonists of your homeworld. This is where the game shines. They automate the micromanagement of individual population units, but you still have to worry non-stop about the politics of your Empire. For example, I uplifted some random animal species and made them intelligent voting members of the Empire. Sects within the Empire popped up centered around the spiritualism of uplifting species, and the animals I uplifted didnt have time to adapt culturally so the became a collectivist entity. One generation later and I have 2 revolts within my Empire happening while I am fighting a war against a robot hive mind. Meanwhile my open migration policy for the last 100 years has caused another sector of my empire to relate more to the bird people Empire than to the humans from Terra, and one system breaks away wanting to be part of an independent protectorate within the Empire. Its well worth checking out. You wont get the cinematic battles of Endless Space, but it is absolutely riveting to play through this game.

												(i know it says ive only played 1.7hrs, but ive played on a different account)Honestly a very fun game to play. I've only played singleplayer due to lack of friends who also play it, but even if I did, I'm not sure I would want to. The amount of events and micromanaging you must do in this game makes me feel like it would be a very confusing and time-consuming multiplayer game.In general, a normal game will take you a while to complete, even if you play on the fastest speeds all the time.It has more micro-managing than Civ 5, but it's not nearly as complicated as Hearts of Iron IV.All in all, a very well put together game and I think its a lot of fun to play, if you like games like Civ and Hearts of Iron.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19
												I love this game, though it took a while to learn since I couldn't find a tutorial, it was so fun. I play this with my friends a lot and still continue to play it as well as try different play styles.Pros:Ship designs looks realistic and really beautiful as well as well thought out.Really fun for any lovers of strategy and anyone who can figure out how to play as the thing that pops up to ask if you want it to explain things to you isn't the best.Great graphics.The music and sound effects fit perfectly and sound great.So much depth and so many different playstyles to choose from.You can customize your own empire according to how you want to play whether you want to be a bit tech savvy, a religious figure of great importance or that one jerk who likes to invade everyones planets right in the beginning of the game.There are so many different types of aliens and enemies and the faction system provides a good challenge.There are so many factions that relate to actual events and they provide an even better enhancement to your game experience.The game is fairly realistic and everything within can be explained luckily so there is no unicorns that blast nuclear jawbreakers from it's booty as much as we all kinda want.Multiplayer is really fun, you can play with other people and even friends.You can be a shroom man..... enough said.The tech tree Cons:The developers thought that by adding this little box in the top right that explains things as you come across them would mean not needing to make a tutorial but it sucks to be honest. It doesnt really explain enything in any real depth and the developers expect you to instantly catch on.You can get a faction called cultists with endgame ships saying they are going to conquer your empire two minutes into the game.One of the ways to win the game is to join a federation of which to join costs -2 influence, though federation gives a lot of perks I would rather there be a penalty if you have a empire that is full of xenophobes or if others in the federation have different values. Rather than influence there should be a penalty for those.The fact that there isnt a single weapon on mining and research stations is kind of annoying because as a base cost it takes -1 energy credit per turn for just one station and now to defend them you need to place defense stations that cost antoher space credit reduction? You also cant even put armor on them so later on about midgame, any ship can one shot them.There really isn't any real materials needed other than energy credits and minerals, which is kind of annoying and restricting.There are materials that boost stats for you if you have a mining station on them but they are otherwise useless.I just want to also point out a lot of time and effort was obviously put into this game and no game is perfect and no dev can truly appease every audience. I would rate this game a 7/10 and would definetly recommend it to anyone who can afford the price XD.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												At 54 hours in, I feel like I can properly review this.I don't generally buy full-price games as I tend to sale-shop and find classics that I have missed, but I purchased this at full price primarily due to the commitment and work done on Cities: Skylines and the work allowed by *a publisher* (Paradox Interactive) to do the right thing.  I do distinguish between developers/publishers yet feel that I will give games a bit more runway when Paradox is involved.I will say that thus far, they are performing exactly as I anticipated.  The praise for Stellaris is justified and the praise of the development team being committed is as well.  Paradox continues to allow resources to flow much more steadily toward continued development of a released game instead of simply abandoning the current product for a cash grab on "Stellaris II" or being completely focused on paid DLC.With each update the game feels like the team has not only taken feedback but reviewed logs and gameplay stats to tweak the playthrough.  As of the Asimov patch, the mid-game has become more interesting, dynamic and engaging.  I would hazard a guess that we will see some more "events" occur to shake up the game with some bit of randomness as things move forward.I will admit, I was tempted to go the new Master of Orion route initially just because I continue to have fond memories of MOO II.  That IP truly defined a genre and the work on the new release is tempting.  But this came down to recognizing that modern gaming is not just about getting it right at release.  It is about sticking around to make the game better even after you've taken your customer's money.  And in the end, that is where I chose Stellaris/Paradox.Game is interesting enough AS IS and playable enough to keep me monkeying with things through several playthroughs.  Updates and potential for additional content just "appearing" like in Cities: Skylines (who turned out the lights?  When did it start snowing in here?) due to this being published through Paradox Interactive means I will give it some additional runway.Right now, it is plenty intuitive (although the sector management took me a bit), enjoyable and interesting.  I haven't even started down the road toward some of the other races and philosophies yet.  I also haven't really made to the "end game" yet due to earlier missteps/restarts.  However, now with the latest patch I'm engaged more and the combination of game improvements and me simply learning the strategies better is leading this to be a much more enjoyable experience.But don't get too cocky dev team.  I still feel like you could drop in some larger universe-effecting events.  Things that might require a large alliance or research treaties to overcome sooner than your opposition to gain an advantage.  And/or some broader effects of leaders dying or ships being lost to make it more "personal" via certain events (e.g. spouse of Captain Smith from Destroyer Devereoux lost at the battle of Apox has gained a following).  And don't think I won't pay for some DLC somewhere along the way, but really, just keep going.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												I lost my saves, so i'm making another review.The Rakaran Holy Empire was an economic tank, with heavily well-developed systems surrounding it's rich home system. By the time space piracy came, the Rakarans were more than dwarfing the pirates.But then came first contact. Aliens were discovered with a fleet the size of a pirate one. Upon the discovery, the Rakarans attacked the fleet. It was only until they were identified that they were seen as a threat, but also as an opportunity.The Ess'Jaggon Assembly, a giant democracy, was rich. It was full of massive mineral deposits (in comparison), filled to the brim with possible worlds, and, best of all, not capitalized by the Ess'Jaggon. Thus, the Rakarans knew their desires.The 10 Year Space War:The war was declared, and a sudden rush of Rakaran forces hit their frontier station, knocking them back and freeing some of the richest worlds. Moving around the capital's fortified stations, they moved south, deeper inland through their southern enemies. When they come to the system of Ulassia, they bombard the planet of Kraajl. The bombardment was met with no resistance.Then, the Ess'Jaggon attacked. Their first fleet to be thrown at the Rakarans at Kraajl. The first battle of Kraajl, consisting of equal fleets duking it out, was a slim victory for the Rakarans, and a minor setback for the Ess'Jaggon Assembly. Seeing his guard down as the Ess'Jaggon constantly rebuild their fleet stronger and stronger, the God-Emperor Nalarik orders the construction of the 1st Defense Fleet, to make up for the exposed core.But the 1st Defense Fleet would have to act as an escort. The transported armies of the Rakarans would be destroyed and the 1st Corvette Crusaders whom had been the blockade force for Kraajl would have to intervene again in the system, sparking the Second battle of Kraajl.The battle would turn out a slim victory once again, with the numbers of the Corvette Crusaders thin as ever. They would be renamed to the 1st Rakaran Crusaders for their bravery. Meanwhile, the 1st Defense Fleet took a risk, moving quickly whilst a new Ess'Jaggon fleet was rising above, with a military power of 118 whilst the escorts had 175. They had a slim opening of which to push through in, but they arrive. The planet has to be bombarded again.The desperate Ess'Jaggon launched a final attack on the besiegers, making the final battle of the war before the invasions. The Third Battle of Kraajl was a pyyrhic victory. The Rakaran Crusaders, numbering a proud 15 (estimated) corvettes pre-war, was now a measly 3 corvettes, with 85 in military power. The construction of the 2nd Defense Legion (Later to merge with the Rakaran Crusaders post-war) was completed. Though it saw no battle, it would keep the Ess'Jaggon from launching invasions over in the core worlds. An estimated 8-9 years had passed since the declaration of war.During the war, minor skirmishes and outpost raids were occuring, far from the savannas of Kraajl.Months pass. The bombardment is complete, and the armies land on Kraajl. The final battle of the war. The 2nd Transport Fleet had landed. The battle, a decisive victory, marked the surrender of the Ess'Jaggon. The Ess'Jaggon Assembly was no more, with their homeworld, Jaggo, going to the Rakarans, as to where the historic battlefield of Kraajl became it's own independent military dictatorship. The war, beginning in 2214, ends in 2224.4.15, 10 years later, with a victory for the Rakaran Holy Empire.2 years later, with the rising rebellion in Jaggo striking constantly, the collapse of the colony of Bysh III and Jaggo occured. Starvation plagued the colonies, even briefly in Rakaras. Though the economy was stable, the production itself wasn't.But yet, all would be well. The establishment of governors and the creation of hydroponic farms would help.But then....The Jhabbanid Horde War: From the east emerged a corporation, XenoCorp, which would prove vital, for the West had a massive threat that wasn't checked by the Rakarans, the Sovereign Jhabbanid Union.Four worlds full of Jhabbanids, odd Arthropoid scientists with their established Science Directorate. This directorate, seeing the exploitable weakness that plagued the Rakarans almost three years after the war, declared their own war, attempting to sieze the colonies and humiliate the Rakarans. The Rakarans thought that they would be fine in this war, until a force of 1,000 military power poured out from the western border system of Yirba. Quickly they moved to Bysh, past the homeworld of Rakaras, remeniscent of the tactics used by the Rakarans themselves in the 10 Year Space War,  and bombarded the colony of Bysh III with fierce speed. The Rakarans were in for a major fight.The Rakaran Crusaders were numbered at a mere 300, the 1st Defense fleet at 175. Seeing the excess wealth of Energy Credits, the Rakarans decided to trade for Minerals at XenoCorp to create a quick fleet that would halt the attackers. This would take longer than imagined. Yet the colonies were secured with numerous armies that would safeguard the colonies from major attack. The race of time began.The Rakarans couldn't even push in their lands, for a border force of 1,000 power held it. They could only work with XenoCorp, sit tight in their homeland, and count their blessings. The Rakarans would not back down.The Rakarans hastily increased the military power of the Rakaran Crusaders, now having a military power in the 640's. But it wasn't enough. Who knows what could be forged behind the closed doors of Yirba.To be continued...WILL UPDATE AS I PLAY

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12
												"From the Sun comes Life. From Life comes Death. From Death comes the Dust. From the Dust is born a new Sun. Such is will of Anaar, that which is all and none, the beginning and end, the Watcher of Creation and Chaos. In its unending dream may we find purpose. In its fearful shadow may we spread throughout the cosmos." -Excerpt from the Book of Ntuloak, Holy Text of the Anaari.Okay, so there is my little contribution to the science fiction atmosphere of this surprisingly deep game. Stellaris is a Grand Strategy game. Unlike other strategy games involving squads of soldiers flung at the opposing team's base, Stellaris puts you in the shoes (figuratively speaking) of the ruler of species in cosmic space. From there, you will be in charge of growing your civilization throught the galaxy. Whether this is by scientific discovery, spiritual diplomacy, or militaristic conquest, the choice is yours for how you choose to rule the stars. Stellaris has a rather steep learning curve. Expect to have several playthroughs before finally finding a government type that suits your tastes. I personally chose the egalitarian and xenophile approach (I am a nice person, can't help it). They might be digitized pixels, but I prefer to be on the good side of cosmic entities. There is a considerable amount of resource management to Stellaris; do not expect the game to be fast-paced. A great deal of patience is required for a successful playthrough. The fascinating thing about Stellaris is that it is much like a black hole; by the time you realize you are being pulled in, it has already consumed you. The game offers a rich, storytelling experience in the same skein as Sunless Sea, where the story develops as a constantly evolving narrative. Your culture does not stagnate. The research options available, coupled with the anomalous events in space, can have drastic and sometimes dire consequences depending upon the choices you make. Stellaris is a fascinating mixture of space sim, empire builder, resource management, and civics simulator.  If you are a fan of wandering through the stars and creating your own story amidst breathtaking beauty, it is definitely worth the purchase. See you in Space!
