content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												After over 300+ hours of play time I can review this game properly.The game itself is a Space RTS, which I know a lot of people go "meh" but, this one ain't bad trust me.Pros:Lots of quest! After 300+ hours i am still finding new quest I haven't seen before.The ability to customize your race of space peeps is really awesome. lots of room to play around even without mods.Hours, an hours of conquest and diplomacy in game. Sometimes you have to pick your battles an sometimes its better to bite your lip an lose a world or 2 than lose everything. UP TO 30 MAN MULITPLAYER GAMES! so sick of 5v5 RTS games being the max.The Game is accessable to mods on the steam workshop! MAKE THE GAME HOW YOU WANT! (anime girls for everyone!)Cons:The AI imo is dumb as rocks, Def. subscribe to a mod to increase the AI difficulty. If you don't, usually what happens is. After you beat the AI's main fleet, it usually just spams you with 1 man fleets OVER AND OVER AND OVER again. It never really recovers to try and "re-Fleet" to fight you again.Multiplayer is Peer to Peer, THIS IS THE ONE HUGE LETDOWN of mulitplayer. Getting the right host is everything. An getting a host to stay and keep the game up after he/she has died is another issue all together. Host PC crashes too bad game over. MABYE! someone will rehost the save game....mabye...an mabye! SOME people might rejoin you. Most just tend to start a new game. After playing 4+ hours into a game its beyond annoying. This game NEEDED! servers for this kind of mulitiplayer.Exclusive Races not avaliable in game or through DLC unless you bought one of the more expensive versions of the game. Its a great game it really is but its not worth $70.00 to make sure you have some extra outfits for your race / all new races. I mean the normal version without any of that is already $40.00. (the one i bought btw) Even the $50.00 one is a bit of a stretch. I would get the normal version an wait for some DLC to come out for those races / outifts which most games tend to. Pay $5.00 in DLC to recive the extras is more reasonable imo.Over all great game 8/10. Def. love the space empire domination an the fact I can mod it up hard core just adds to the already hundreds of hours of gameplay. Its a must have for RTS fan's an space nerds alike.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19
												I love this game, though it took a while to learn since I couldn't find a tutorial, it was so fun. I play this with my friends a lot and still continue to play it as well as try different play styles.Pros:Ship designs looks realistic and really beautiful as well as well thought out.Really fun for any lovers of strategy and anyone who can figure out how to play as the thing that pops up to ask if you want it to explain things to you isn't the best.Great graphics.The music and sound effects fit perfectly and sound great.So much depth and so many different playstyles to choose from.You can customize your own empire according to how you want to play whether you want to be a bit tech savvy, a religious figure of great importance or that one jerk who likes to invade everyones planets right in the beginning of the game.There are so many different types of aliens and enemies and the faction system provides a good challenge.There are so many factions that relate to actual events and they provide an even better enhancement to your game experience.The game is fairly realistic and everything within can be explained luckily so there is no unicorns that blast nuclear jawbreakers from it's booty as much as we all kinda want.Multiplayer is really fun, you can play with other people and even friends.You can be a shroom man..... enough said.The tech tree Cons:The developers thought that by adding this little box in the top right that explains things as you come across them would mean not needing to make a tutorial but it sucks to be honest. It doesnt really explain enything in any real depth and the developers expect you to instantly catch on.You can get a faction called cultists with endgame ships saying they are going to conquer your empire two minutes into the game.One of the ways to win the game is to join a federation of which to join costs -2 influence, though federation gives a lot of perks I would rather there be a penalty if you have a empire that is full of xenophobes or if others in the federation have different values. Rather than influence there should be a penalty for those.The fact that there isnt a single weapon on mining and research stations is kind of annoying because as a base cost it takes -1 energy credit per turn for just one station and now to defend them you need to place defense stations that cost antoher space credit reduction? You also cant even put armor on them so later on about midgame, any ship can one shot them.There really isn't any real materials needed other than energy credits and minerals, which is kind of annoying and restricting.There are materials that boost stats for you if you have a mining station on them but they are otherwise useless.I just want to also point out a lot of time and effort was obviously put into this game and no game is perfect and no dev can truly appease every audience. I would rate this game a 7/10 and would definetly recommend it to anyone who can afford the price XD.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												The race designer is fantastic, offering plenty of different ways of exploring and dominating the galaxy. The early game exploration phase is brilliant and to be honest, doesn't really need any serious improvements with plenty of interesting events and quest chains. The moment where you meet your first alien civilisation never gets old, will they be friends or arch enemies? The mid-game is where things get a little bit stale, with the diplomacy and politics being rather shallow. However, I still find them enjoyable and there is plenty of room to make it better later on down the line. The AI is an area of weakness. Usually its competent but on occasions it can be incredibly stupid. Fortunately, Paradox are releasing a patch to fix the more serious flaws soon. There are definitely bugs, although I personally have yet to find a serious or game breaking one. At the moment the game is definitely lacking depth in places, but I'm still having a hell of a time and would recommend anyone who has even a vague interest to give this game a go.

If you like grand strategy games or any paradox games it is definitely worth it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												The race designer is fantastic, offering plenty of different ways of exploring and dominating the galaxy. The early game exploration phase is brilliant and to be honest, doesn't really need any serious improvements with plenty of interesting events and quest chains. The moment where you meet your first alien civilisation never gets old, will they be friends or arch enemies? The mid-game is where things get a little bit stale, with the diplomacy and politics being rather shallow. However, I still find them enjoyable and there is plenty of room to make it better later on down the line. The AI is an area of weakness. Usually its competent but on occasions it can be incredibly stupid. Fortunately, Paradox are releasing a patch to fix the more serious flaws soon. There are definitely bugs, although I personally have yet to find a serious or game breaking one. At the moment the game is definitely lacking depth in places, but I'm still having a hell of a time and would recommend anyone who has even a vague interest to give this game a go.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												Best 4X/Strategy game ive ever played.  Makes the recently released reboot of Master of Orion look like child's play.  The amount of detail in each every every star, planet, ship is incredible.  The costumization is at least 100 times better in every way possible than similar games.  The race costumization alone is well worth the price.  Here when you create a HUGE galaxy to play in you ACTUALLY get HUGE.  We're talking over 1000 star systems with 5-10 various stellar bodies in each. And on top of that you can populate the galaxy with 39 other randomly generated species to play against! How amazing is that?? Compare that to the new Master of Orion where a HUGE galazy is only 100 star systems at best and only 7 other species to play against.  Just an astounding game on every level.  Buy it now!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												Stellaris is big. Really big. You just won't believe how vastly, hugely, mind-bogglingly big it is. I mean, you may think it's a long way down the road to the chemist, but that's just peanuts to Stellaris. Adams quotes aside, the game is pretty good. There's fun to be had in creating an empire, in the early-game space exploration, and in most aspects of the game. Unfortunately, an unforunate amount of the mid-late game time is filled with busywork or nothing at all, but speeding up the game can help things along quite a bit. The AI Diplomacy leaves something to be desired, for example some empire might reject your Non-Agression Pact because it's "Not Diplomatically Relevant" which somehow manages to appear in just about every situation, near, far, big, small, worried, peaceful, it will show up and say "No, no diplomacy for you." tl;drGame is pretty good, but overpriced. Wait for a sale if you like this sort of gameplay and don't mind a little bit of busywork between the exciting things that happen. I expect this game will get better with time, the diplomacy will be more intuitive, bugs will be patched out, so the older this review gets, the more likely it is that the issues with the game will become history.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
												"Worthy of the hype." - Me, just now. I was sceptical of Stellaris. I've tried other 4x games and few of them hit the spot. But Stellaris had me from the start. I think the visuals help - there's not a hexagon in sight! The richness of the scifi is great too - I could roll-play a book I'm reading (Pandoras Star, Peter F Hamilton) and it's reminiscent enough of other SciFi - Ian Banks, Stephen Baxter and so on that I feel like those stories could be taking place in the Stellaris' Universe. It's a slow-paced game but it's not turn based - you can control the speed at which the un-paused game passes so if nothing interesting is happening till you build your next Colony Ship (for example) then you can speed things up - so slow-paced but not boring in the way I found Gal Civ 3 for example. Watch a Let's Play, then get the Galaxy Edition (cdkeys gave the best deal at time of writing) to also enjoy a novel, sound track and other goodies.Top tip - for your first game I'd recommend playing against only minor races till you learn the ropes.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												-Addicting space strategy opera-This seems like the Galatic Civilisation 2-successor I wanted except it's real-time with pause.For the new player: Stellaris plays much like civilization in space including the dreaded "just-one-more-turn-phenomenon".Features:Exploration, expansion, extermination (optional) or cultural/diplomatic win.Different ethics highly change your playstyle e.g. with xenophobe you only get mean first contact hails to select. In democracies the boss is selected among your leaders which mixes your staff around and so on.Context sensitive random event and crisis system, large scale galactic threat events.You can add planets to sectors under AI control so you don't have to micromanage your large empire. Indeed you have a cap for solitary planets.Game is highly modable.Space looks nice.No performance problems or crashes for me.-minor bad things-There's an extensive tutorial but many conccepts are still cloudy (on the other hand there's also a wiki built-in)Some UI bugs and fighting with the controls and finding infos. Try to uplift a species for example. Pause is your friend here.If you play a lot events become repetative but more will be added later I guess.It could be even weirder but then I'm also reading Rhodan so take that with a grain of salt.-mixed feelings-Games really depend on your neighbors and where you start as you're never far ahead in the tech/power race in this game even in "normal".If you want achievements you'll have to play ironman (only one autosave slot).Death and ruin can come quickly in space. You will take losses of beloved admirals and beautiful worlds. I personally rage quit after an "ally" snatched a key planet away with a colony ship only 3 seconds ahead of my own colony ship.My best admiral started taking drugs then died ahead of her time.TLDR; you can buy that, it's good.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												After over 300+ hours of play time I can review this game properly.The game itself is a Space RTS, which I know a lot of people go "meh" but, this one ain't bad trust me.Pros:Lots of quest! After 300+ hours i am still finding new quest I haven't seen before.The ability to customize your race of space peeps is really awesome. lots of room to play around even without mods.Hours, an hours of conquest and diplomacy in game. Sometimes you have to pick your battles an sometimes its better to bite your lip an lose a world or 2 than lose everything. UP TO 30 MAN MULITPLAYER GAMES! so sick of 5v5 RTS games being the max.The Game is accessable to mods on the steam workshop! MAKE THE GAME HOW YOU WANT! (anime girls for everyone!)Cons:The AI imo is dumb as rocks, Def. subscribe to a mod to increase the AI difficulty. If you don't, usually what happens is. After you beat the AI's main fleet, it usually just spams you with 1 man fleets OVER AND OVER AND OVER again. It never really recovers to try and "re-Fleet" to fight you again.Multiplayer is Peer to Peer, THIS IS THE ONE HUGE LETDOWN of mulitplayer. Getting the right host is everything. An getting a host to stay and keep the game up after he/she has died is another issue all together. Host PC crashes too bad game over. MABYE! someone will rehost the save game....mabye...an mabye! SOME people might rejoin you. Most just tend to start a new game. After playing 4+ hours into a game its beyond annoying. This game NEEDED! servers for this kind of mulitiplayer.Exclusive Races not avaliable in game or through DLC unless you bought one of the more expensive versions of the game. Its a great game it really is but its not worth $70.00 to make sure you have some extra outfits for your race / all new races. I mean the normal version without any of that is already $40.00. (the one i bought btw) Even the $50.00 one is a bit of a stretch. I would get the normal version an wait for some DLC to come out for those races / outifts which most games tend to. Pay $5.00 in DLC to recive the extras is more reasonable imo.Over all great game 8/10. Def. love the space empire domination an the fact I can mod it up hard core just adds to the already hundreds of hours of gameplay. Its a must have for RTS fan's an space nerds alike.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3
												Oh boy, here we go...War score system:      Forcing you to play within the limitation of the war goal and also Capping the War score at 100 is stupid and illogical. We are essentially limiting a pan-galactic empire to the rules of some primitive feudal state. All this does is it artificially slows down the game by forcing wars to last centuries instead of a few years. Let us ignore the obvious thematic and logical issues of this design choice and just look at mechanics: This system works somewhat well when you are nothing but a couple of fledgling empires slugging it out in the local clusters, but once you have a large alliance or federation it becomes incredibly frustrating to play with. Here are some obvious ones: If you have more than 4 allies, it is almost impossible to make war against someone as most planets are worth ~20 warscore apiece.Diplomacy:    This simply isn't fleshed out enough, there are no meaningful interaction between empires beyond the most simplistic ground rules (Alliance, enemies, rivals etc.). There isn't even a gifting/tribute system! I can give my allies a million credits/minerals and they will still not like me one bit better than if I did not. This also makes relationships relatively permanent outside of some trite predetermined 'diplomatic actions' like insult or rivalry. I can conquer the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of someone and as long as I don't personally keep any of the loot, they won't even bat an eye a year later.Technology Tree:     There is no real way to influence which tech you get beyond memorizing the arcane multiplication table between researcher traits and the various gain rates. It makes zero thematic sense that the overlord of an empire cannot tell its researchers to put more effort into an area. I don't necessarily want a guaranteed chance, but at least give me a way to throw credits/influence to increase the probability of one of the techs showing up. I had the misfortune in my last game to be surrounded by 20+ arid planets but could not find the colonization tech to take them until well into the mid-late game. Incredibly frustrating, makes little logical sense and makes the game random in such a way that is unfun. It is entirely possible to have your race spawn in a corner of the galaxy without any naturally colonizable planets and then never get the colonization techs. This ends the game without you ever making a mistake..Technological Growth/Research:     The time it takes to research a tech is increased by the number of pop you have in your empire. Logically, this is the OPPOSITE of what should happen in real life as more people tend to produce more scientists with more chances of discovering things. From a design point of view, this decision to tie population with tech only serves to punish players who prefer to be expansionist or who are aggressive early on. You have a technological edge if you have a small focused empire, since technology has no real limit in this game, this eventually just becomes a tax on every player. Thus, the only mechanical result of this design is to slow down games to a crawl. AI, as usual, does not appear to have this problem. It is also possible that their natural 'cheats' to research rate overcomes this in large part. In the last game I played, the larger enemies actually out tech'd me at a faster rate than the smaller ones (I'm behind even the smallest empire, even though I have every single one of my 122 planets focused on research).As a direct consequence of you always being technologically inferior to most of your rivals, you simply cannot allow a game to last longer than a century or so. The '5% tech' that you get at the end of the tech tree means that AI empires will infinitely out-scale you and eventually will overcome even the largest of industrial capacity disparities.Strategic Combat:    There is no consequence in letting a fleet rampaging through your sectors. There is no concept of 'defending your territory'. Economic damage is almost irrelevant and even holding planets does not accomplish much at all. This is a huge problem when you are fighting large empires (30-40 planets or more) as fighting becomes tedious and inconsequential. This is especially true if you have hundreds of planets in the late game of large galaxies. The only objective that matters are the enemy's fleets and your only real war goal is to kill their big fleet stacks. If the AI raids a dozen of your planets but you nail his fleet, then you win. Period. Even if the warscore is -99%, you will still get your planets back as long as your fleet survives and his doesn't.There isn't' really a way to prevent a fleet from running through your systems either: Defensive stations tend to be pathetically weak compared to ships, they are also extremely expensive and difficult to stack. This leads to enemy AI sending dozens of tiny raiding parties into your territory, murdering everything they can get their hands on. Especially once they get jumpdrive tech. The only way to ensure victory against AI is to cluster your shipyards in one or two systems, put ALL of your defenses in those stations and always have a fleet nearby to protect it. The rest of your empire literally does not matter. As long as you have production capabilities, you will win every war. In fact, having as little assets outside of those few production sectors is key in not losing the war as you will still lose warscore by losing small and inconsequential space battles.If there is a single optimal way to win the strategic game, then your design is fundamentally flawed. This is compounded by the fact that AI excels at performing annoying but not game-winning actions.End game Crisis:   This is only a crisis for you, Ai doesn't apparently care about any of the big galaxy ending events. You can't even tell your ally fleet to follow into combat against any of them, nor will they react diplomatically in anyway. I had my ally declaring multiple wars(or had rivals declaring wars on me even as they are being eaten alive by the threat) while I'm trying to deal with these events and nearly cost the game for me.Sectors(Flaw/bug): AI governors are dumb as bricks. At the same time, Sector automation is indispensable in this game. I've seen AI filling up planets with +23 food when the pop is already full (or even when the pop doesn't consume food, like synths and robots). Telling them to focus on a specific thing or telling them to respect tiles only seem to work some of the time. Very little work seems to have gone into making the sectors actually work properly.Strategically, the segregation between sector space assets and core world assets is also very annoying. You can't really tell sectors to produce ships because it becomes a nightmare to micro them without them showing up in the sidebar. This actually changes how one plays the game because warfleets are difficult/impossible to produce in non-core worlds and your production ends up being limited to how many core planets you possess. This becomes enormously problematic once your empire gets large - in large or gigantic maps, you can't produce ships fast enough to fight a 100+ planet empire because the AI apparently does NOT have this problem with user interface and micromanagement.This is just some of the things I noticed in my prelim play throughs. There are other things that I do not agree with but did not include because they are preference related. TL;DRStellaris is a really amazing 4x game and I think it has built the right foundations for one of the most amazing strategy games of all time. However, there are many questionable design choices in the game that I feel limits strategic variety or pidgeonholes the player in some illogical way. I for one am glad that paradox is embracing the modding community as it will take a tremendous amount of support from them to make this game truly meet its potential.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												The race designer is fantastic, offering plenty of different ways of exploring and dominating the galaxy. The early game exploration phase is brilliant and to be honest, doesn't really need any serious improvements with plenty of interesting events and quest chains. The moment where you meet your first alien civilisation never gets old, will they be friends or arch enemies? The mid-game is where things get a little bit stale, with the diplomacy and politics being rather shallow. However, I still find them enjoyable and there is plenty of room to make it better later on down the line. The AI is an area of weakness. Usually its competent but on occasions it can be incredibly stupid. Fortunately, Paradox are releasing a patch to fix the more serious flaws soon. There are definitely bugs, although I personally have yet to find a serious or game breaking one. At the moment the game is definitely lacking depth in places, but I'm still having a hell of a time and would recommend anyone who has even a vague interest to give this game a go.

Posted: May 10, 2016
												Best 4X/Strategy game ive ever played.  Makes the recently released reboot of Master of Orion look like child's play.  The amount of detail in each every every star, planet, ship is incredible.  The costumization is at least 100 times better in every way possible than similar games.  The race costumization alone is well worth the price.  Here when you create a HUGE galaxy to play in you ACTUALLY get HUGE.  We're talking over 1000 star systems with 5-10 various stellar bodies in each. And on top of that you can populate the galaxy with 39 other randomly generated species to play against! How amazing is that?? Compare that to the new Master of Orion where a HUGE galazy is only 100 star systems at best and only 7 other species to play against.  Just an astounding game on every level.  Buy it now!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												Stellaris is big. Really big. You just won't believe how vastly, hugely, mind-bogglingly big it is. I mean, you may think it's a long way down the road to the chemist, but that's just peanuts to Stellaris. Adams quotes aside, the game is pretty good. There's fun to be had in creating an empire, in the early-game space exploration, and in most aspects of the game. Unfortunately, an unforunate amount of the mid-late game time is filled with busywork or nothing at all, but speeding up the game can help things along quite a bit. The AI Diplomacy leaves something to be desired, for example some empire might reject your Non-Agression Pact because it's "Not Diplomatically Relevant" which somehow manages to appear in just about every situation, near, far, big, small, worried, peaceful, it will show up and say "No, no diplomacy for you." tl;drGame is pretty good, but overpriced. Wait for a sale if you like this sort of gameplay and don't mind a little bit of busywork between the exciting things that happen. I expect this game will get better with time, the diplomacy will be more intuitive, bugs will be patched out, so the older this review gets, the more likely it is that the issues with the game will become history.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												It's very hard not to just type 'OMG...IT'S FREAKIN' AMAZING!'....But I won't (of course!).As someone who has loved 4X Space games but always wanted to go into a more empire controlling late-game & someone who has loved the IDEA of getting into EU4 but found the learning-curve too steep to get past....Stellaris has provided all I've wished for and more.While not a direct comparison in genre, Stellaris is the first game to capture that day-long space stratedgy bliss I got from Star Trek: Birth of the Federation. The 4X/Slow based beginnings eases you into the game and the mid-late game eases in allowing for a smooth learning experience helped by the in-game advisor.If a more in-dept 4x game is something you've craved then this is a must. If the idea of a Paradox game daunts you, know that it means a deep end-game without the learning curve and future support rarely seen from other developers....oh yeah and the soundtrack is phenomenal!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												I cautiously recommend it. It's a good game, but it has some features that people might not like.The negatives:Highly depends on RNG. I do not usually call it a negative, but the only events that matter have negative influence on the wellbeing of your empire: if you are not prepared, it's a game over. As these particular events - yes, I'm talking about crisises - happen in late game, all your progress becomes nullified, which sometimes can be rather annoying. Customisation is wast, yet is restricted. You have to choose the presents, not the bonuses directly, which in my opinion could push the customisation to it's glorious limits.Wars are not great. You can't control directly your fleet. Conquering the planes is a redundant mini-game that slows you down - simply because you use soldiers only when you have won all the space battles and is bombing the plants' fortification - taking them without bombing is 75 times harder for armies.AI is weird, just like in your usual strategy game of this genre.Yes, this is a positive review. The game itself is good and easily enjoyable. It has something that was making you to make that 'one more turn' in Civilization games.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												A good game with great potentials. The baseline is there, but it needs improvemnts. Pros:- Good technology development idea (Semi-random cards).- Atmosphere. - Government types, edicts, ethos and its effects on empire level.- Preferred planet types.- Ship designs. Cons:- Fights involves no tactics, just bigger and better designed army wins.- Species does not vary one from another (Biggest let down for me), all use same tech tree, same approaches. - Leader limits, but why. (Makes no sense, if I have proper economy, I should be able to hire as many as I want)- Tech is mostly for army level, not good improvements are introduced for society level, and the ones for society does not affect enough. Neutral:- Sections. (AI does fair job but sometimes I want to control those planets)I think it is a good game, but can be much more.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22
												My first Steam Review on my first 4x game (seems quite fitting).   I'll start off with a TL;DR...if you want a quality game with both beautiful audio and visuals, which also includes fun gameplay with massive replayability, just buy this now.   I was a little nervous when I first started the game.  Never having played a game in the genre before, I wanted to win!  I started/re-started two games of about 30 minutes each, just to get the hang of basic functions.  Third time was the charm and as of this writing, I'm about 20-some-odd hours into my first true play through.  I realized quite quickly that it didn't really matter if I won or not as a beginner...the journey is just so much fun.   I'm playing fairly conservatively, just looking out for my peoples and not ruffling any feathers.  I have not been into any battles with any other species but have amassed enough territory, resources, and a strong enough fleet that I am more powerful than many of the species that dislike me.  I am also friendly with over half of all of the advanced species, so I feel like I could easily gain support if I need it.   Regardless of how it all plays out, I am looking forward to either continuing to victory or to my next play through.  With so many choices to make due to the options provided, my next "warlike" tribe will decimate all who oppose me.  Then religious zealots who will convert everyone into happiness.  After getting comfortable with a few different playstyles, it'll be multiplayer time, where I can try my hand with non-AI counterparts.  I absolutely love this game, and I'm glad that I took the chance on it.  You should take the chance as well.   If you made it this far, thanks for taking the time to read my ramblings.  I don't know how this compares to other games in the genre, but I can whole heartedly recommend this to anyone who loves video games, has a bit of imagination, patience, and is ready for an amazing adventure.  Easy to pick up, hard to put down (I now know the "one more turn" mentality), this game is downright spectacular!

Posted: May 14, 2016
												This is a good game but it definitly needs a lot of work. Sometimes the end game crisises bug out and you're stuck with the everlasting invaders that do nothing. Another complaint is that the whole galaxy doesn't care about th invaders. Now after you've sorted all that out there are only two ways to win: Dominate the whole galaxy or control 40% of all planets. There aren't many passive options for pacifist empires or spiritual empires. Don't get me wrong, in my first playthrough I was a pacifist empire and I loved playing it, but once you research all the technologies and defeat the evil hordes of end game enemies you just have to integrate your vassals and colonize whatever planets are left to get the domination victory. Overall its a good game, needs a lot of work though. Buy it if you want to, but I suggest waiting three or four updates. The one major thing that does bug me is the inly two victory conditions. I suggest Victory conditions based on your empure's ethics and government type. NEED MORE VICTORY CONDITIONS!!!!!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												After so many disappointments, especially regarding these high priced games that aren't even finished properly, it was genuinely refreshing to see a company come along that actually gives a ♥♥♥♥ about providing content to the gamers that buy their games.This game seem to play out very much like Sins of a solar empire, except without the silly superpowers and abilities that the ships get and it's on a much more massive scale with more intricate 4x style empire management. What's great though is it doesn't have the 4x turn based play and is all real-time so you don't have hideously long wait times for a turn to happen. I thought that would be overwhelming at first as I suck at micro-management, but because you can tweak the speed whenever you like and pause things to issue commands it's all very friendly to the more casual players.The diplomacy isn't completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like most of these empire management games, the AI actually seems to follow a set of logic and I've managed to make some friends. I chose materialistic and fanatical individual, I also chose direct democracy, so I had an easy time allying with likeminded races once I started exploring and finding other empires.The galaxy map is also pretty nice along with all the artwork they've put in, the map reminds me a lot of those custom made maps of EVE Online if you've ever seen them on the internet where they actually have the alliance borders and symbols plastered all over 0.0 space. Except of course in this game, it's actually fun to play and go to war or use diplomacy with the various factions.

												It's a good game; but like most games at launch, it has its initial problems and bugs. Knowing Paradox, it'll get smoothened over in a reasonable amount of time. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												What I, a Filthy Casual, thinks:The last sci-fi strategy game I played was Galactic Civilizations III and this game is similar but with a lot more depth (and this game hasn't even been out as long right now so there are a host of free updates and expansion packs to look forward to). This review is not aimed at hardcore strategy players who are looking for their next tactical fix.+ Many species designs for your aesthestic pleasure+ Mix and match a variety government types + A choice of galaxy sizes & shapes (blob/spiral arm/ring)+ Pre-space age planets (not other empires) that can be probed, enslaved or enlightened+ Make a fleet! Name the fleet! Name the ships! Name the Admiral! SEND IT TO WAR!+ Rename all the stars you own to goofy names and stupid references 'cos why not+ Micromanage EVERYTHING unlike real-life where you have no control+ Make sectors when your empire gets too big and micromanaging becomes a chore+ Optional pop-up missions (plotlines!) with various rewards+ A burgeoning modding community to add extra flavour+ Involved developers offering updates and new content in the future!- Limited tutorial, no in-game help- Can modify weapons on ships but cannot alter appearance like in GalCiv III- Diplomacy (pacifist) options limited and not fun. Can't make friends easily like in Civilization- Seriously, why do all my neighbouring empires hate me?! THEY DON'T EVEN KNOW ME.- For scaredy cats: cannot avoid hostiles early in-game (no option to turn them off)- For impatient people: cannot hammer out a game in a day like in CivilizationWord to the one sitting on the fence:If you've never played a 4X or grand strategy game before, or are a Filthy Casual like me, this game does kind of throw you into the deep end a little. The game isn't turn-based, it runs time like The Sims with pause, slow, faster options (recommended: pause when making decisions and reading stuff). Anyway, don't feel scared to potter around in a couple false starts games in order to get to grips with the game mechanics before you look up a few Beginner's Tutorials. From there on, when you encounter something you need more information, there is a really helpful community and forum archive available full of answers.If you're not afraid of time sinks, love exploring, love building and managing empires, and have the patience to play the long game then this game is definitely worth it (it's not even that expensive).

content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
												Stellaris is a fun game, at least for me.It has it's issues but the devs have been actively working on quality of life and bug fixing updates and it couldn't make me happier. They've taken a lot of community input when it comes to balancing and other small things.My only gripe is that the game is really intensive resource wise late game. Due to just the sheer size of your fleets, empire and neighboring empire's fleets the game slows down a LOT. Battles that'd take less than a minute had it been just 25 destroyers quickly turn into 5-10 minute slug fests ending in one side attempting to flee and being caught by the chasers or a fleet being destroyed.End game Victory conditions are also a bit lack luster with the two Conditions being, get rid of every other empire or colonize a majority of the Galaxies planets. There's also a massive mid game slog, but if you can push through it all and are dead set on conquering the galaxy this game is for you.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												After so many disappointments, especially regarding these high priced games that aren't even finished properly, it was genuinely refreshing to see a company come along that actually gives a ♥♥♥♥ about providing content to the gamers that buy their games.This game seem to play out very much like Sins of a solar empire, except without the silly superpowers and abilities that the ships get and it's on a much more massive scale with more intricate 4x style empire management. What's great though is it doesn't have the 4x turn based play and is all real-time so you don't have hideously long wait times for a turn to happen. I thought that would be overwhelming at first as I suck at micro-management, but because you can tweak the speed whenever you like and pause things to issue commands it's all very friendly to the more casual players.The diplomacy isn't completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like most of these empire management games, the AI actually seems to follow a set of logic and I've managed to make some friends. I chose materialistic and fanatical individual, I also chose direct democracy, so I had an easy time allying with likeminded races once I started exploring and finding other empires.The galaxy map is also pretty nice along with all the artwork they've put in, the map reminds me a lot of those custom made maps of EVE Online if you've ever seen them on the internet where they actually have the alliance borders and symbols plastered all over 0.0 space. Except of course in this game, it's actually fun to play and go to war or use diplomacy with the various factions.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
												This early impression (given its a paradox title) is aimed specificly at fans of EU IV (as I am) wondering whether they should get stellaris. Please bear in mind that this is no full review of stellaris.The game starts out much more like a civilization game than an EU game. You start with a singular solar system, scout you surroundings, meet enemies and neighbors, build mines to collect resources and send out colonists to expand your empire. Sounds familiar? You also develop technologies along a tech tree, have random events and kill pirates (think barbarians). Even the classification of your race (spiritual, industrious, militaristic, pacifistic ...) reminds me strongly of civ IVs classification of leaders.Now, I am not saying this is civ in space. However playing stellaris to me has a lot more in common with said titles as any paradox title I know. It starts out pretty simple and straight forward. You start on your own and for the first years you are pretty much expanding without much trouble. After all, your competitors are more or less on your level of power, technology and resources. The amount of micro management grows proportionately to your empires size, which means after a while you'll be busy managing all those planets. Eventually you'll get into conflict with a neighbor who, depending on your play style, may have little more or less military power than you.The point is, that this is a pretty fair game. Everyone starts the race more or less equal and your success largely depends on your system mastery. Even the fact that success is a thing (I dare you to define success in EU IV) makes a massive difference. There are traditional win states such as "have the largest empire" or "kill everyone else".EU IV in contrast is a completely unfair game. Whether you start as mighty France or little Albania (if you're insane), the game is never balanced. Some nations are doomed from the beginning and making it to the year 1821 for them is a major achievement. Other nations might strive for world domination.I like stellaris and I'm sure I'll get my money's worth out of it. But for me something is lost in the balanced race to supremacy. EU can be impenetrable with its interface and its complex systems. It can be cry out loud harsh when apparently out of nowhere an alliance rises against you. But setting my own goals, playing as a super power or a tiny monastery fighting against the odds is what keeps EU interesting to me. I don't see how stellaris can do the same.I hope these impressions help to set expectations for the game correctly. I will update this text if I find that I was wrong or have further remarks.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14
												If you're more of fan of historical Paradox strategy games like Europa Universalis, Crusader Kings, or Hearts of Iron, I would highly recommend downloading an overhaul mod that sets the game in a sci-fi universe, like Star Wars, Star Trek, Mass Effect, et cetera. This makes the geopolitics at game start more dynamic and asymetrical, just like other Paradox games.If, however, you're more of a space 4x fan and like games like Masters of Orion, Imperium Galactica, or Sword of the Stars, I'd recommend setting the number of civilizations in your galaxy to about 80% of the recommended value, because otherwise it ends up feeling like there is very little time or space to enjoy the explore phase of Stellaris.Essentially, it feels to me like Stellaris is trying to be both types of games simultaneously, but falls short a little bit of the hype and its goals in its initial design. I guarentee though, that with the numerous inevitable expansions, it will undoubtedly improve tremendously.Either way, it is an enjoyable game in its own right, even if it won't be able to fill the Masters of Orion shaped hole in our lives.

												I Declared War On a Galaxy-Spanning Federation of Empires --- And I Won All Four Cede Planet Goals.It really doesn't seem worth it, to be honest, but the fighting was awesome when I stopped trying to pin down invasion fleets and just resorted to terror-bombing their homeworlds to lure them out (after counter-invading lost worlds, of course).Maybe you're supposed to conquer the galaxy through mass vassalization and integration, rather than directly?In retrospect: Probably. content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												There are many issues with this game, but holy crap it's been a long time since I've played a game for 12 hours straight on my first session.  Issues aside, this is a great game that will get better with a little love from the devs.Some of the issues I've noticed are:-Mid game border cluster♥♥♥♥s where you can't really interact with people you don't have a border with.  (Without getting military access to space that lies inbetween you, the devs have stated they are working on this.)-Mediocre Ai that are great in some areas and terrible in others. (Ai are also too passive in some situations and highly predictable from a diplomatic POV.)-Lack of any form of major diplomatic UI such as color coding alliances, Ai's opinion of other factions, ect.-Too few victory conditions?  (This is more my personal opinion, just look at how many ways you can win in Civ)-Lack of internal/external trading.There are certainly a few more, but I believe these are the major points.All in all, I've put nearly 60 hours into a game that was released just under 2 weeks ago.  The UI is pretty good in most areas, and it was surprisingly easy to pick up when compared to Paradox's other games.  I've thoroughly enjoyed this game so far and I can't wait to see what future updates and expansions are on their way.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												Good game crippled by a bad UI.  A lot of things 4X players would expect to see such as auto-explore options for scout ships weren't even in at launch.  The planet/sector management interface is sorely lacking in sorting options.  There is no interface to view potentially colonizable planets, and the only way to do so is by hovering over the galaxy map looing for green planet icons that disappear if you zoom too far out.That said, the events and race designs are really well done, though the AI seems to balk at the eXpand portion of the 4x genre.  Almost 200 years into a playthrough there were still a LOT of habitable planets on the edge of the galaxy that were sitting uncolonized.  The endgame threats are cool though, and I'm looking forward to what the game will look like in 3-6 months with some TLC centered on the mid game lull and UI shortcomings.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												IF you are as old as me, you can appreciate when I say, this game brings me back to the pure joy, and occasionally the frustration, I had when I played the ORIGINAL Sid Meier's Civilization back in 1991 -- that's 25 years ago!I remember playing Civ back then, not realizing how much time had passed, and how how quickly it passed, all because this GAME swept you up in its wonderful 4x mechanics -- and that's what I'm reliving now with Stellaris.  Sure, it's got a few flaws, but between patches and mods, you can fix or tweek just about anything you might find to complain about.So this isn't so much of a technical review, as it's much more of a thank you to Paradox for bringing that feeling back -- bravo, folks, bravo!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												I've been enjoying Stellaris a lot so far, but I have a few issues with it:+Epic Scale, the largest galaxies can have 1000 Star Systems, each with multiple planets+Beautiful Graphics, the battles look great, weapon effects and sounds are good for the most part+Customization of Species traits, Government, Appearance, Names etc.+Ship design, a very user friendly ship design+Multiple interesting events and locations to explore+Different FTL systems that really change how you play and explore the Galaxy+Long term epic strategy, you can take a species that you discover on a planet from Iron Age tech up to eventually be assimilated into your Empire as an equal member-species (It takes a long time, but I've done it!)-Limit of 5 planets (Initially, can be increased through tech) that you directly manage. You have to create 'sectors' to control more. The AI that manages you sectors really sucks, I had to take a system out of a sector and manage it myself for a while then put it back it as the AI wasn't doing anything I asked it to do. I supplied the sector with plenty of resources to build up those planets within its control.-No tech tree, you get a draw of 3 techs to research (initially, you receive more through exploring and tech upgrades) It makes it hard to plan out what tech you want to research initially, but with further play this might be less of an issue-limited trade with other species, I had a surplus of energy and shortage of minerals, but I couldn't trade away my surplus fast enough to supplement my mineral requirements. The AI usually wants to have a better deal than you are getting otherwise it will reject it. Also, sometimes they won't even trade with you despite you giving them a huge advantage, they still feel insulted that you offered them that deal??-AI for enemies sucks because they all hate you for going for the win conditions. Its really annoying actually.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19
												I love this game, though it took a while to learn since I couldn't find a tutorial, it was so fun. I play this with my friends a lot and still continue to play it as well as try different play styles.Pros:Ship designs looks realistic and really beautiful as well as well thought out.Really fun for any lovers of strategy and anyone who can figure out how to play as the thing that pops up to ask if you want it to explain things to you isn't the best.Great graphics.The music and sound effects fit perfectly and sound great.So much depth and so many different playstyles to choose from.You can customize your own empire according to how you want to play whether you want to be a bit tech savvy, a religious figure of great importance or that one jerk who likes to invade everyones planets right in the beginning of the game.There are so many different types of aliens and enemies and the faction system provides a good challenge.There are so many factions that relate to actual events and they provide an even better enhancement to your game experience.The game is fairly realistic and everything within can be explained luckily so there is no unicorns that blast nuclear jawbreakers from it's booty as much as we all kinda want.Multiplayer is really fun, you can play with other people and even friends.You can be a shroom man..... enough said.The tech tree Cons:The developers thought that by adding this little box in the top right that explains things as you come across them would mean not needing to make a tutorial but it sucks to be honest. It doesnt really explain enything in any real depth and the developers expect you to instantly catch on.You can get a faction called cultists with endgame ships saying they are going to conquer your empire two minutes into the game.One of the ways to win the game is to join a federation of which to join costs -2 influence, though federation gives a lot of perks I would rather there be a penalty if you have a empire that is full of xenophobes or if others in the federation have different values. Rather than influence there should be a penalty for those.The fact that there isnt a single weapon on mining and research stations is kind of annoying because as a base cost it takes -1 energy credit per turn for just one station and now to defend them you need to place defense stations that cost antoher space credit reduction? You also cant even put armor on them so later on about midgame, any ship can one shot them.There really isn't any real materials needed other than energy credits and minerals, which is kind of annoying and restricting.There are materials that boost stats for you if you have a mining station on them but they are otherwise useless.I just want to also point out a lot of time and effort was obviously put into this game and no game is perfect and no dev can truly appease every audience. I would rate this game a 7/10 and would definetly recommend it to anyone who can afford the price XD.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12
												"From the Sun comes Life. From Life comes Death. From Death comes the Dust. From the Dust is born a new Sun. Such is will of Anaar, that which is all and none, the beginning and end, the Watcher of Creation and Chaos. In its unending dream may we find purpose. In its fearful shadow may we spread throughout the cosmos." -Excerpt from the Book of Ntuloak, Holy Text of the Anaari.Okay, so there is my little contribution to the science fiction atmosphere of this surprisingly deep game. Stellaris is a Grand Strategy game. Unlike other strategy games involving squads of soldiers flung at the opposing team's base, Stellaris puts you in the shoes (figuratively speaking) of the ruler of species in cosmic space. From there, you will be in charge of growing your civilization throught the galaxy. Whether this is by scientific discovery, spiritual diplomacy, or militaristic conquest, the choice is yours for how you choose to rule the stars. Stellaris has a rather steep learning curve. Expect to have several playthroughs before finally finding a government type that suits your tastes. I personally chose the egalitarian and xenophile approach (I am a nice person, can't help it). They might be digitized pixels, but I prefer to be on the good side of cosmic entities. There is a considerable amount of resource management to Stellaris; do not expect the game to be fast-paced. A great deal of patience is required for a successful playthrough. The fascinating thing about Stellaris is that it is much like a black hole; by the time you realize you are being pulled in, it has already consumed you. The game offers a rich, storytelling experience in the same skein as Sunless Sea, where the story develops as a constantly evolving narrative. Your culture does not stagnate. The research options available, coupled with the anomalous events in space, can have drastic and sometimes dire consequences depending upon the choices you make. Stellaris is a fascinating mixture of space sim, empire builder, resource management, and civics simulator.  If you are a fan of wandering through the stars and creating your own story amidst breathtaking beauty, it is definitely worth the purchase. See you in Space!

content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												I lost my saves, so i'm making another review.The Rakaran Holy Empire was an economic tank, with heavily well-developed systems surrounding it's rich home system. By the time space piracy came, the Rakarans were more than dwarfing the pirates.But then came first contact. Aliens were discovered with a fleet the size of a pirate one. Upon the discovery, the Rakarans attacked the fleet. It was only until they were identified that they were seen as a threat, but also as an opportunity.The Ess'Jaggon Assembly, a giant democracy, was rich. It was full of massive mineral deposits (in comparison), filled to the brim with possible worlds, and, best of all, not capitalized by the Ess'Jaggon. Thus, the Rakarans knew their desires.The 10 Year Space War:The war was declared, and a sudden rush of Rakaran forces hit their frontier station, knocking them back and freeing some of the richest worlds. Moving around the capital's fortified stations, they moved south, deeper inland through their southern enemies. When they come to the system of Ulassia, they bombard the planet of Kraajl. The bombardment was met with no resistance.Then, the Ess'Jaggon attacked. Their first fleet to be thrown at the Rakarans at Kraajl. The first battle of Kraajl, consisting of equal fleets duking it out, was a slim victory for the Rakarans, and a minor setback for the Ess'Jaggon Assembly. Seeing his guard down as the Ess'Jaggon constantly rebuild their fleet stronger and stronger, the God-Emperor Nalarik orders the construction of the 1st Defense Fleet, to make up for the exposed core.But the 1st Defense Fleet would have to act as an escort. The transported armies of the Rakarans would be destroyed and the 1st Corvette Crusaders whom had been the blockade force for Kraajl would have to intervene again in the system, sparking the Second battle of Kraajl.The battle would turn out a slim victory once again, with the numbers of the Corvette Crusaders thin as ever. They would be renamed to the 1st Rakaran Crusaders for their bravery. Meanwhile, the 1st Defense Fleet took a risk, moving quickly whilst a new Ess'Jaggon fleet was rising above, with a military power of 118 whilst the escorts had 175. They had a slim opening of which to push through in, but they arrive. The planet has to be bombarded again.The desperate Ess'Jaggon launched a final attack on the besiegers, making the final battle of the war before the invasions. The Third Battle of Kraajl was a pyyrhic victory. The Rakaran Crusaders, numbering a proud 15 (estimated) corvettes pre-war, was now a measly 3 corvettes, with 85 in military power. The construction of the 2nd Defense Legion (Later to merge with the Rakaran Crusaders post-war) was completed. Though it saw no battle, it would keep the Ess'Jaggon from launching invasions over in the core worlds. An estimated 8-9 years had passed since the declaration of war.During the war, minor skirmishes and outpost raids were occuring, far from the savannas of Kraajl.Months pass. The bombardment is complete, and the armies land on Kraajl. The final battle of the war. The 2nd Transport Fleet had landed. The battle, a decisive victory, marked the surrender of the Ess'Jaggon. The Ess'Jaggon Assembly was no more, with their homeworld, Jaggo, going to the Rakarans, as to where the historic battlefield of Kraajl became it's own independent military dictatorship. The war, beginning in 2214, ends in 2224.4.15, 10 years later, with a victory for the Rakaran Holy Empire.2 years later, with the rising rebellion in Jaggo striking constantly, the collapse of the colony of Bysh III and Jaggo occured. Starvation plagued the colonies, even briefly in Rakaras. Though the economy was stable, the production itself wasn't.But yet, all would be well. The establishment of governors and the creation of hydroponic farms would help.But then....The Jhabbanid Horde War: From the east emerged a corporation, XenoCorp, which would prove vital, for the West had a massive threat that wasn't checked by the Rakarans, the Sovereign Jhabbanid Union.Four worlds full of Jhabbanids, odd Arthropoid scientists with their established Science Directorate. This directorate, seeing the exploitable weakness that plagued the Rakarans almost three years after the war, declared their own war, attempting to sieze the colonies and humiliate the Rakarans. The Rakarans thought that they would be fine in this war, until a force of 1,000 military power poured out from the western border system of Yirba. Quickly they moved to Bysh, past the homeworld of Rakaras, remeniscent of the tactics used by the Rakarans themselves in the 10 Year Space War,  and bombarded the colony of Bysh III with fierce speed. The Rakarans were in for a major fight.The Rakaran Crusaders were numbered at a mere 300, the 1st Defense fleet at 175. Seeing the excess wealth of Energy Credits, the Rakarans decided to trade for Minerals at XenoCorp to create a quick fleet that would halt the attackers. This would take longer than imagined. Yet the colonies were secured with numerous armies that would safeguard the colonies from major attack. The race of time began.The Rakarans couldn't even push in their lands, for a border force of 1,000 power held it. They could only work with XenoCorp, sit tight in their homeland, and count their blessings. The Rakarans would not back down.The Rakarans hastily increased the military power of the Rakaran Crusaders, now having a military power in the 640's. But it wasn't enough. Who knows what could be forged behind the closed doors of Yirba.To be continued...WILL UPDATE AS I PLAY

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												I've logged quite a few hours on this title already, and I'm already anticipating many many more to come.Personally, I love the game.  It has (almost) everything I want in a 4x space game; heavy emphasis on early game exploration, event chains emulating my favorite sci-fi tropes, and big gnarly space ships blasting the crap out of each other. The domestic and foreign politics systems are a bit thin for what I was expecting from paradox, but I imagine that will flesh out in time.  Even stripped down, the government and diplomatic options are still far and away more sophisticated then the usual 4X space fare I've seen in the last 10 years (with the exception of Distant Worlds).  In fact, Stellaris reminds me of one of my favorite games from the 4x genre: the Space Empires series.  Just with updated graphics, real time / pause, and a dash of the usual paradox stuff.Stellaris does what it does very well, and it's firmly rooted in the 4X genre.  If you are expecting it to be more complex and fiddly like other paradox titles, or a soap opera simulator like CK2....well it definitely isn't either of those things.  It has less in common w/ other paradox titles than it does with 4x games like Civ, Galactic Empires, or Endless Space.  The fussy micromanagement stuff isn't there yet, but it seems like more of the more complicated systems will be added over time with patches and expansions. The AI, whether working for you or against you, needs some work.  The sector system feels artificial and isn't especially well explained.  It doesn't feel organic.  The faction system feels bare bones.  Diplomacy does what you would expect from a 4x, but there could be more done with it.  From what I've seen combat systems could be expanded on, especially fighters/bombers and capital ship effectiveness.  Even with that, I absolutely recommend the game for space fans, 4x fans, and strategy fans in general.  It hits just enough of the right notes to make me feel like I'm participating in a sci fi story of my own.  For me everything else is just details.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												An absolutely amazing space 4X game that brings some new twists and life to the genre. Before I go on, know that there are some issues with the game as it is now. Late game ends up a bit lacking, and the interface needs some work. Diplomatic communication and AI needs a small upgrade too. BUT, don't think the game is unplayable if these things worry you. If you pick up this game, my advice to you, is grab your favorite sci-fi, and roleplay it. This game is unprecedented on the feeling it gives you as the leader of your empire. It IS your empire, and it IS your guys that are being badass. It's kinda hard to put it in words, but you are going to end up immersed and that familiar "One more turn" feeling that sucks you down the rabbit hole, will hit you HARD. As it is now, this game is one of my all time favorites, right up there with the classics, and it's only going to get better. Paradox has always had extensive support with updates and fantastic DLC after launch. And you can mod this game with the same fervor you mod Skyrim, just waiting on those total conversion mods, yum. So yes. Recommended with high marks.

Posted: September 15, 2016
												Personally, I haven't been this engrossed in a 4X style game since Moo2, Alpha Centauri, or Civ 4.Stellaris does an amazing thing - it lets you weave a story, and its primary concern is the immersion of the player in the world it's created. You won't find Civ 5 style AI here, waging wars against you for the sole reason that you're approaching a victory condition and need to be stopped - an amazing amount of attention is paid to making the game world have interesting personalities. You will not forget the first time you accidentally♥♥♥♥♥♥of an ancient, fallen empire of religious guardians and their fleet waltzes in to obliterate the colony that trespasses on their holy world.Stellaris draws a ton of inspiration from classic science fiction series, like Asimov's Foundation, Iain Bank's Culture series, Star Trek, 2001, Brin's Uplift saga and others. It's a very affectionate homage to the genre.Pros:Great tutorial, not as intimidating as other Paradox gamesGood graphicsEffective mix of free-form traditional 4X style stuff with written story elementsGreat race/empire creationCons:UI is a bit clunkyTendency towards doomstack combat (being addressed a bit by next patch..)Victory conditions are almost entirely forgettable (but the journey is fun)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												Without a doubt the most impressive 4X game I've ever played. Never in my time playing various iterations of the Civilization franchise, Command & Conquer, Age of Empires, or any other similar title have I encountered a more difficult AI. Playing this game on the most simplistic difficulty setting will still leave you racking your brain for the solutions that left you with all these problems. A single misstep in the beginning of the campaign will come back to haunt you with detrimental catastrophe so much farther along in the campaign that you have no hope of figuring out what that crucial mistake could have been. I was floored by the delightfully complex need to micromanage everything all the way down to the planetary level. Even when getting to the point of a campaign in which it becomes necessary to establish sectors within your galactic empire, one must still monitor the growth of people as well as their political opinions and agendas. A magnificent title that I would recommend on sale, at full price, or even at a higher dollar value. What a marvelous game. Truly.Five Stars

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
												I'm in the middle of my first playthrough still, with basic Humans. Already like it a lot. The empire-building is well thought out, exploration is very engaging and rewarding, the style and design are nearly perfect. I like the balance between war and exploration, the details of world colonization, research and ship management. Resources are made interesting again here, by the way, as they all behave in different ways and you need to maintain their flow by taking different measures for each (I mean credits, minerals, influence, strategic resources). It looks and feels like a near-perfect space 4X game to me, although I've never played any other game of that type, coming to this one after CK2 and Civs.There are some mildly boring things though. Firstly, I've not noticed yet any differences in Species, game-wise. I mean they all have different traits and affinities, but beyond preferring certain climates otherwise they behave similarly. Even in diplomacy the difference between species and ideologies converts to just simple liking/disliking. Then, to make it better for non-warlike players, perhaps other victory conditions could be added, Civ-style, and then I think many would appreciate more nuanced diplomacy and sector management (like ordering your Governor to address certain issues first or to pursue a certain policy beyond basic resource extraction). Also the border instability should be explained somewhere in a tutorial. Your territory expands and contracts slightly all the time, depending on how active your planets are, and this came as a minor surprise.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2016
												By far my favorite 4X game I've ever played. There are so many random occurrences and unforseeable possibilities with each game (not to mention multiplayer) that it's completely impossible to play anywhere near the same game twice. What I found really fun when I first started playing is seeing all the other empires form around me and peeking over at them to see what they were doing right. Kind of like cheating on a test. That meant that after I inevitably went bankrupt while waking the sleeping bear by attacking someone's vassal, I could then use everything I'd learnt and build on it from the start.Even during my second playthrough when I'd had a really strong grasp on how things worked and the tactics involved in keeping up with your peers, I still found myself at the mercy of my neighbors and their impressions of me. Suddenly the empire east of me wouldn't hear me out at all and started encroaching on my borders en masse. It made me have to rethink my entire strategy and declare war on the smaller friendly empire to the west. This allowed me to expand further in that direction and buy myself time while I caught up in naval superiority to my easterly rivals (although I felt dirty for crushing those poor colonies).Naturally, the whole cold war between myself and the other was rendered a moot point when I researched Jump Warp Drives that accidentally tore a portal open in the fabric of spacetime and unleashed a bunch of ethereal beings onto the galaxy. Proceeded to completely eat up my neighbor and my empires both. BUT IT WAS ENJOYABLE.Onto game #3, using my previous two empires as templates for some of the AI so I can face myself in a way haha. During each game you pick different traits for your species and different policies for your empire so you wind up playing differently anyway, no matter how well you know the game. First time around I was a military dictatorship, second time around an individualist democracy and now I'm going for a materialistic logician oligarchy of sorts, all of which play entirely differently and massively dictate how the game molds to you.Long winded, anecdotal "review", sorry about that, but hopefully the genuine satisfaction I get from this game comes through. As of writing this I'm at 29 hrs played and I got it less than 2 days ago :3

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17
												I've got some reservations recommending this game, but I can't hit that thumbs down button because it's entertaining for at least one hundred hours before you start noticing it coming apart at the seams. I'm reviewing version 1.5.1 and all the DLC available as of April 2017. This game will continue to be updated, so hopefully the issues I'm about to list will be addressed.Stellaris is a sci-fi 4x game. It may perhaps be THE sci-fi 4x game. It covers very many angles of science fiction, you can re-create almost any sci-fi scenario in Stellaris. If it's not available in the base game, it's probably in a DLC or someone's modded it in. If you like galactic-scale science fiction and/or 4x games, you're going to like this game.Pros:+ Good soundtrack of space music. You don't know what space music is? It's this kind of stuff.+ Sound effects are good. Nothing too outstanding here, but it's appropriate.+ A lot of love went into the graphics for the stellar bodies, and it's soothing to watch pulsars or black holes or planets spin on their axis.+ Good writing. Since most events and diplomacy are conveyed through writing, this is good. You can ignore it if you hate reading, but you'll miss out on the feel of being part of a novel.+ Strong early game with lots of exploration events.+ Lots of attention to detail everywhere.Meh:? Notable lack of graphics for a lot of in-game events, or a small number of still images are re-used. Don't expect unique art every time something happens, but to compensate a lot of stuff seems to happen.? Endgame is a bit nebulous (hah). One of several end-game events that will happen if you have the setting turned on, and these are alright. There's some fun end-game shenanigans you can do with genetic manipulation or building mega-structures, but by the time you get to them, you'll already either won or lost.Cons:- Graphics engine chugs during the endgame with lots of on-screen ships.- Emaciated middle. I hope you're ready to put the game on the fastest speed and just churn though technologies while you micromanage your holdings and build up a blob fleet of death. Slightly alleviated with the Leviathans DLC, but it's not enough.- Diplomacy is almost nonexistent.- Federations (large alliances) are a huge waste of time thanks to the way the AI flounders with the federation fleet.- No espionage or intrigue between empires. You can infiltrate pre-FTL worlds, but empires can't touch each other.- The game attempts to discourage you from micromanaging your planets and heavily penalizes you if you go over your Core World limit, but the sector AI that you're supposed to use instead is inscrutable and dumb. This ironically results in more and more frustrating micromanagement.- Space combat consists entirely of throwing as large a fleet as possible at the enemy. There are no tactics, there are no formations, just balls of death. - Ground combat is even worse because it's also a blob, but you don't even see the lasers and missiles, just numbers and HP bars on a screen.- War in general is a slog due to how demands work. It can take several wars with a 10-year truce between to conquer or eradicate an enemy, because the game won't allow you to take more from the enemy than it deems fit.- Tall empires are not feasible because by the time you research the technologies that allow construction of tall empires you've already lost because of the huge disadvantage you have of spending the first two thirds of the game as a small empire.- Despite all the different aliens feeling different because of appearance and ethical attitudes, they all have the same weapons on their ships, they all have the same hydroponic farms, and they all have the same mining stations.That looks like a lot of cons, huh? Well, there's a lot of other mechanics that do work and will keep you busy so that it's still fun for a while before you start noticing the downsides.

												I Declared War On a Galaxy-Spanning Federation of Empires --- And I Won All Four Cede Planet Goals.It really doesn't seem worth it, to be honest, but the fighting was awesome when I stopped trying to pin down invasion fleets and just resorted to terror-bombing their homeworlds to lure them out (after counter-invading lost worlds, of course).Maybe you're supposed to conquer the galaxy through mass vassalization and integration, rather than directly?In retrospect: Probably. content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												What I, a Filthy Casual, thinks:The last sci-fi strategy game I played was Galactic Civilizations III and this game is similar but with a lot more depth (and this game hasn't even been out as long right now so there are a host of free updates and expansion packs to look forward to). This review is not aimed at hardcore strategy players who are looking for their next tactical fix.+ Many species designs for your aesthestic pleasure+ Mix and match a variety government types + A choice of galaxy sizes & shapes (blob/spiral arm/ring)+ Pre-space age planets (not other empires) that can be probed, enslaved or enlightened+ Make a fleet! Name the fleet! Name the ships! Name the Admiral! SEND IT TO WAR!+ Rename all the stars you own to goofy names and stupid references 'cos why not+ Micromanage EVERYTHING unlike real-life where you have no control+ Make sectors when your empire gets too big and micromanaging becomes a chore+ Optional pop-up missions (plotlines!) with various rewards+ A burgeoning modding community to add extra flavour+ Involved developers offering updates and new content in the future!- Limited tutorial, no in-game help- Can modify weapons on ships but cannot alter appearance like in GalCiv III- Diplomacy (pacifist) options limited and not fun. Can't make friends easily like in Civilization- Seriously, why do all my neighbouring empires hate me?! THEY DON'T EVEN KNOW ME.- For scaredy cats: cannot avoid hostiles early in-game (no option to turn them off)- For impatient people: cannot hammer out a game in a day like in CivilizationWord to the one sitting on the fence:If you've never played a 4X or grand strategy game before, or are a Filthy Casual like me, this game does kind of throw you into the deep end a little. The game isn't turn-based, it runs time like The Sims with pause, slow, faster options (recommended: pause when making decisions and reading stuff). Anyway, don't feel scared to potter around in a couple false starts games in order to get to grips with the game mechanics before you look up a few Beginner's Tutorials. From there on, when you encounter something you need more information, there is a really helpful community and forum archive available full of answers.If you're not afraid of time sinks, love exploring, love building and managing empires, and have the patience to play the long game then this game is definitely worth it (it's not even that expensive).
