number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3
												Oh boy, here we go...War score system:      Forcing you to play within the limitation of the war goal and also Capping the War score at 100 is stupid and illogical. We are essentially limiting a pan-galactic empire to the rules of some primitive feudal state. All this does is it artificially slows down the game by forcing wars to last centuries instead of a few years. Let us ignore the obvious thematic and logical issues of this design choice and just look at mechanics: This system works somewhat well when you are nothing but a couple of fledgling empires slugging it out in the local clusters, but once you have a large alliance or federation it becomes incredibly frustrating to play with. Here are some obvious ones: If you have more than 4 allies, it is almost impossible to make war against someone as most planets are worth ~20 warscore apiece.Diplomacy:    This simply isn't fleshed out enough, there are no meaningful interaction between empires beyond the most simplistic ground rules (Alliance, enemies, rivals etc.). There isn't even a gifting/tribute system! I can give my allies a million credits/minerals and they will still not like me one bit better than if I did not. This also makes relationships relatively permanent outside of some trite predetermined 'diplomatic actions' like insult or rivalry. I can conquer the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of someone and as long as I don't personally keep any of the loot, they won't even bat an eye a year later.Technology Tree:     There is no real way to influence which tech you get beyond memorizing the arcane multiplication table between researcher traits and the various gain rates. It makes zero thematic sense that the overlord of an empire cannot tell its researchers to put more effort into an area. I don't necessarily want a guaranteed chance, but at least give me a way to throw credits/influence to increase the probability of one of the techs showing up. I had the misfortune in my last game to be surrounded by 20+ arid planets but could not find the colonization tech to take them until well into the mid-late game. Incredibly frustrating, makes little logical sense and makes the game random in such a way that is unfun. It is entirely possible to have your race spawn in a corner of the galaxy without any naturally colonizable planets and then never get the colonization techs. This ends the game without you ever making a mistake..Technological Growth/Research:     The time it takes to research a tech is increased by the number of pop you have in your empire. Logically, this is the OPPOSITE of what should happen in real life as more people tend to produce more scientists with more chances of discovering things. From a design point of view, this decision to tie population with tech only serves to punish players who prefer to be expansionist or who are aggressive early on. You have a technological edge if you have a small focused empire, since technology has no real limit in this game, this eventually just becomes a tax on every player. Thus, the only mechanical result of this design is to slow down games to a crawl. AI, as usual, does not appear to have this problem. It is also possible that their natural 'cheats' to research rate overcomes this in large part. In the last game I played, the larger enemies actually out tech'd me at a faster rate than the smaller ones (I'm behind even the smallest empire, even though I have every single one of my 122 planets focused on research).As a direct consequence of you always being technologically inferior to most of your rivals, you simply cannot allow a game to last longer than a century or so. The '5% tech' that you get at the end of the tech tree means that AI empires will infinitely out-scale you and eventually will overcome even the largest of industrial capacity disparities.Strategic Combat:    There is no consequence in letting a fleet rampaging through your sectors. There is no concept of 'defending your territory'. Economic damage is almost irrelevant and even holding planets does not accomplish much at all. This is a huge problem when you are fighting large empires (30-40 planets or more) as fighting becomes tedious and inconsequential. This is especially true if you have hundreds of planets in the late game of large galaxies. The only objective that matters are the enemy's fleets and your only real war goal is to kill their big fleet stacks. If the AI raids a dozen of your planets but you nail his fleet, then you win. Period. Even if the warscore is -99%, you will still get your planets back as long as your fleet survives and his doesn't.There isn't' really a way to prevent a fleet from running through your systems either: Defensive stations tend to be pathetically weak compared to ships, they are also extremely expensive and difficult to stack. This leads to enemy AI sending dozens of tiny raiding parties into your territory, murdering everything they can get their hands on. Especially once they get jumpdrive tech. The only way to ensure victory against AI is to cluster your shipyards in one or two systems, put ALL of your defenses in those stations and always have a fleet nearby to protect it. The rest of your empire literally does not matter. As long as you have production capabilities, you will win every war. In fact, having as little assets outside of those few production sectors is key in not losing the war as you will still lose warscore by losing small and inconsequential space battles.If there is a single optimal way to win the strategic game, then your design is fundamentally flawed. This is compounded by the fact that AI excels at performing annoying but not game-winning actions.End game Crisis:   This is only a crisis for you, Ai doesn't apparently care about any of the big galaxy ending events. You can't even tell your ally fleet to follow into combat against any of them, nor will they react diplomatically in anyway. I had my ally declaring multiple wars(or had rivals declaring wars on me even as they are being eaten alive by the threat) while I'm trying to deal with these events and nearly cost the game for me.Sectors(Flaw/bug): AI governors are dumb as bricks. At the same time, Sector automation is indispensable in this game. I've seen AI filling up planets with +23 food when the pop is already full (or even when the pop doesn't consume food, like synths and robots). Telling them to focus on a specific thing or telling them to respect tiles only seem to work some of the time. Very little work seems to have gone into making the sectors actually work properly.Strategically, the segregation between sector space assets and core world assets is also very annoying. You can't really tell sectors to produce ships because it becomes a nightmare to micro them without them showing up in the sidebar. This actually changes how one plays the game because warfleets are difficult/impossible to produce in non-core worlds and your production ends up being limited to how many core planets you possess. This becomes enormously problematic once your empire gets large - in large or gigantic maps, you can't produce ships fast enough to fight a 100+ planet empire because the AI apparently does NOT have this problem with user interface and micromanagement.This is just some of the things I noticed in my prelim play throughs. There are other things that I do not agree with but did not include because they are preference related. TL;DRStellaris is a really amazing 4x game and I think it has built the right foundations for one of the most amazing strategy games of all time. However, there are many questionable design choices in the game that I feel limits strategic variety or pidgeonholes the player in some illogical way. I for one am glad that paradox is embracing the modding community as it will take a tremendous amount of support from them to make this game truly meet its potential.

content:
Posted: March 7
												After spending over 175 hours playing Stellaris, I feel I have a good idea about the game to write this review. Mind you all that even after all this time, I am still learning/experiencing new things about this game, so keep that in mind. When you first load in you're presented with a lot of premade empires, which is great for new people to get a feel for the game and it's mechanics. Each empire has it's own ethics and government, which allows/denies them certain abilities like purging/enslaving aliens, as well as how your empire reacts to war.  You are able to make your own empire and design it to fit the play-style you want, which I have done multiple times. Each of the ethic and government choices you pick are personal preference, there isn't one that is the best, though other's will disagree with me, but it ultimately comes down to what you want. After you start playing you'll have the choice to do the tutorial, which has two modes (one is full and the second is partial) or skip it all together. I would strongly recommend you use the full tutorial for your first few times playing so you can get a better grasp on the vastness of this game. Before you start playing you will see a screen that allows you to create the 'perfect' game, though sometimes it might not be, and I'll explain in a bit what I mean. From the screen you can choose how big you want the galaxy to be, ranging from a small map (150 stars) to a huge map (1000 stars). there you are able to change how you want the galaxy to look, how many alien empires you want and how many of them are more advanced than you, as well as the aggressiveness of the AI and the difficulty. One option I always have issues with is the placement, where you can either be clustered together (meaning the AI will be close by) or randomly placed. No matter which option I choose I am always next to the AI, even if I choose a huge map with 1 AI, but I digress. Now that you have messed around with these settings and you launch into the galaxy for the first time, it can be a bit daunting, even on small maps I still find myself a small spec in the cosmos. One thing that I do love the most is that each map is randomly generated, meaning everything is different each time you start over. As you explore the nearby systems you learn more about the galaxy, or at least what was before. The majority of the time I get the precursor event chains where I have to search for artifacts left behind and figure out what happened to them. Other times you might find yourself with a mass extension event where you have to search the stars for clues on how to save your own empire, all of these are random and rather interesting, but after a few times playing you get a feeling of repetitiveness, for right now there's only four events at the start. ------------politics!!!-------------------------------- As you explore the stars you will encounter alien races and depending on how you manage to interact with them (based on your first contact protocols) they might favor or loath you. this can be changed but I feel that it does little because the AI goes off of your ethics when making decisions about how to treat your empire. Although they might distrust you at first, you're more than able to befriend them in time, or turn against those who are quick to accept alien life as allies, the choice is (mostly) up to you. -----------researching!!---------------------------As you progress in your research, you unlock new tech which allows you to progress and expand your boarders. from colony ships to massive energy weapons, the choices are many, but eventually you will learn everything and then will be left with repeatable research options. Though they will help late game, it does get a bit tiresome researching the same thing over and over again.---------------------Combat!-----------------Combat is broken up into two parts, for the most part. Space battles and ground battles. the AI does a good job for the most part with determining who would win in a battle. As you build up your fleet, it grows in fleet power, the more ships you have, the more guns/missiles/lasers you have. When you do go to war, you really want to have more fleet power than your enemy, or else the losses you will receive will be great and could possibly cost you the war. When you go to war (Either by declaring war on someone else or having them declare war on you) there are a lot at stake. Some of the war-goals range from just being humiliated among the galaxy to losing your planets. in every war (either attacking or defending) you have the option of setting the war-goals, so make sure that even if you manage to be on the defensive end of a war, you might be able to take some of their planets. When war is declared you can win by either destroying their entire fleet, or bombarding their planets. there's three options to bombard their planets, light, limited, or full. For the most part you start out with the first two but you might be able to change the ethic to allow full bombardment. After you take down the planetary defenses you can send in ground troops to invade, and if they win the battle the planet is under your control for the duration of the war. One thing I've learned about the AI is even if they start the war with you, they will divert their forces and try to retake the planets they've lost. During the war there is a progression icon with a percentage icon, and the more you win, the more it grows. However if you start losing it will start going into the negative which means the enemy is winning. Once it gets to around 50-60% it will turn either green or red (again, depending on if you're winning or not) which allows you  or the enemy to negotiate terms for the end of the war. Once it gets closer to 100% (if you're winning) the AI will concede and the war will be over. How the war goes is up to you. And there are other factors that go into play but this should give you a good idea of how things are done.------------END GAME EVENTS!!!-----------------One of the best things about this game, is the end game events. They are randomly generated events that could easily end the game not only for you, but for the AI in general. Some of the events are preventable, based on your research and ethics but others will happen in time. If you're lucky the events will be a challenge, if not then they will be damn near impossible. I'm not going to spoil them here, just make sure you have the option turned on to have a great end game challenge. -----END OF REVIEW/FINAL THOUGHTS-----This game is good, and the devs are fantastic with communicating with the players from what I've seen. I would strongly recommend this game to people.

content:
Posted: April 24
												A lot of people give a pretty one-on-one description of what kind of stuff happened in their games. Because interstellar war is no joke, I decided to use a metaphor to describe one of my playthroughs in Stellaris.  Imagine having a very rude and obnoxious next-door neighbor who terrorizes everyone in the neighborhood. This neighbor has several kids whom he keeps under strict supervision. His kids, and everyone else in the neighborhood dislike the guy. One day, one of his kids runs away and asks if they can stay at your place, because you’re a cool guy. Being the nice person you are you agree and let them in. Neighbor does not like this. Later, another one of his kids runs away and asks if you’re willing to look out for them a bit and in exchange they’ll help you if someone picks a fight with you. They’re weak as hell, but you’re still trying to be chill and say yes. The neighbor doesn’t really care, and decides to let it rest. But sometime after his kids running away, he decides he doesn’t like you, and demands you go work for him. The guy is seriously buff and is much stronger than you are, so you quickly decide to surrender before he can mess you up. This results in you losing most of your freedom and you need to pay a lot of money before you’re allowed to do anything outside of your house. Furthermore, the neighbors with whom you had a pretty high standard pretend you don’t exist anymore. This is pretty awful. So you decide to do something about it. You go train at home. A lot. You become stronger and buffer than that pile of salt so you can stick up to him. Fast forward a few years. You’re not only one of the most well-trained people in the neighborhood, but the jerk of a neighbor has lost a lot of his muscle because he got in several fights with that cranky, crazy neighbor no one wants to mess with. You laugh maniacally inside, and relish the freedom you’ll soon have again. However, bad neighbor made a couple of buff friends who promise they’ll come help if he gets in a fight. Darn. Still, you’re pretty strong so you decide to risk it. You go up to the neighbor and tell him to get lost. He gets angry and attacks you. Luckily for you, you’re so strong you manage to knock him out in basically one blow. Then you go on to wreck his house room by room, until his friends arrive. His friends, however, are woefully unprepared for the 2 meter tall fighter which stands before them. They go at you one by one, and you knock them out too. Eventually, the neighbor gives up and lets you free.  He also rudely tells you to get lost. You’re happy, but you’re also pretty mad at the neighbor for being such a jerk. Being one of the strongest people in the hood, you decide to put insult to injury and occupy a few of the neighbors rooms. He does not like this, and calls for his friends. He and his friends are still weakened by the fight they had with you, and, like the brainless sods they are, also picked another fight with that crazy neighbor. After a couple of fights the jerk has to give up several of his rooms, which you then use for your stuff. It’s still not enough. Finally, you decide to put up a middle finger to the guy who terrorized the neighborhood for years: You’ll force him to give up his house and then be an unpaid slave to you. The only problem is, is that the loser became friends with the strongest person around. This is fairly annoying. They’re still dumb, and are still picking fights with that crazy guy which decimates everyone in a fight. Thus, they’re pretty weakened. So you go on to beat his butt and systematically occupy all of his rooms. He doesn’t want to give up, so you also beat up his friends repeatedly and occupy some of their houses as well. After a couple of years the guy finally gives up, and gives the keys to his house to you, and promises to provide unpaid labor. He hates you, but eventually he finds out you’re a pretty cool guy and starts to like working for you. At last, justice is served, and you’re free to dominate the galaxy with your stellar empire- I mean enjoy life in the neighborhood.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25
												I like CK2 a lot - This is not CK2 in space.I like 4X games - this hits the spot.I love turn based strategy games - This is real time strategy which I don't like, however it feel's like they've just streamlined turn based so you dont have to keep pressing enter. They've done it well (To be honest they just used the same system that works on CK2, but its not CK2 in space - I promise).The inevitable Moo2 comparison : I have played & mostly enjoyed many turn based 4X space games. Most just made me nostalgic for Moo2. Some intoduced good stuff. Some re-hashed stuff already done. Moo3 just had all the enjoyment of doing a tax return with a migraine. This game doesn't play like any of them. It's not a Moo2 clone in any way other than being 4X & set in space. I love Moo2, but after far too long I have now moved on. This game has filled the space I had in my heart for Moo2. It has succeeded it & improved on it.Now about the game :It is very complex but enjoyable from the start - expect to restart quite a bit at first though simply becaus as you learn whats what you learn what you've done & why it's wrong. Or just play it out for as long as you can.There is a lot of customization options to begin with - species - culture - politics - preferences - (probably more I dont remember) each choice you make will potentially open further choices, possible end game victory options or even end game disasters! Additionally there are plenty of options for the galaxy you play in.With the real time gameplay you can speed it up, slow it down or just pause it after every day if you insist it has to be played turn by turn (I did this for a while - change is scary). Eventually you get a feel for how the game is progressing & it just becomes natural.The tech progress is nothing too radical but has been done well & seems balanced. There are three main tech progression paths that have seperate research points allocated to them, and each is slightly randomised so each game will play different.The ship design is interesting & allows a lot of variation while keeping it as simple/streamlined as possible. You start off only building small ships, then cus of tech you get bigger ones, also cus of tech you need to keep them upto date with better weapons etc. Nothing new there, but because of the various restrictions fleets work better with diversity (as in more than one design filled with the best gun you got), and even the original small ship remains useful by being repurposed once certain tech is available - obsolete gunship to torpedo boat for example - You could design a fleet of ships that successfully destroys your one neighbours fleet with ease only to find out it may have a few too many vulnerabilities when faced with your other neighbour. And that's assuming a similar level of tech.The diplomacy works well & covers a lot of options. In addition to this the information on display shows why you are doing good/bad with a particular race. From your original customization options its possible you have just selected the exact oposite choices so you guys will not get along & war is inevitable, or you've just found your long lost twin and friendship is instant, also everything inbetween. Interestingly how you deal with each race, and all the other races, and even your own people is over time taken into account by all the other races.Exploration is interesting & is covered below.***The above is just the standard info that compares to other space based 4X games - now for what makes Stellaris different***You aren't the ruler of a race who started on one planet and reach into the galaxy to claim his/her destiny through conquest/ascension/genocide/glory/oblivion/galactic-appocalypse. Your just not.In this game you design the original planetary leader, but only that one and only because one is needed to begin with.Have you ever read a book or seen a TV show where you thought : I'd do something different, I wonder how that would have turned out. Well this is your chance. This is a fully interactive story that is different every time you go through it. That's what makes this special. Every time you explore somewhere it's exciting - a hundred hours I've played so far & I still love exploring. I'm still encountering new stuff. Even stuff I've encountered in previous games is exciting because I can take those other options.This is the story of the race you chose - the story of their leader's, hero's, war's, friendship's, glory & folly. The story of a race that reaches from one world into the stars & the galaxy is a very dangerous but interesting place.Also if yor not bored yet:Like CK2 Stellaris is made by Paradox - this means it is being updated constantly & new expansion DLC is guaranteed. So the game is getting bigger & better & optionally more expensive. I'm not sure how I feel about that cus most of my CK2 DLC was purchased while drunk, but it was on offer & I really wanted it.Also since I decided I needed the 1st DLC for this I can now play as an imortal(but not un-killable) galactic hive mind. So, playing as a single entity spread accross worlds & star systems I guess I could say it was my story, but I prefer other races & single these abominations out for extermination!!Oh yeh - there's multiplayer - doesn't interest me.

												Now I know most people won't read this. Due to the fact that there are plenty of other reviews on the page that will go into much more detail. But for those of you who do find yourself reading my review, know that this is an amazing game. Though not for everyone. The main reason I recommended this at all is because I love paradox games and know with time this game will only become better. People say when you hit your lowest point the only way to go is up. Well that's stellaris. It's low point is already miles ahead of other games, and still has so much room to grow. If you like previous games by paradox and don't mind the DLC, get it. If you're on the fence or weren't a big fan of the others, wait for a sale. But at some point this game should be in your library.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												There are many issues with this game, but holy crap it's been a long time since I've played a game for 12 hours straight on my first session.  Issues aside, this is a great game that will get better with a little love from the devs.Some of the issues I've noticed are:-Mid game border cluster♥♥♥♥s where you can't really interact with people you don't have a border with.  (Without getting military access to space that lies inbetween you, the devs have stated they are working on this.)-Mediocre Ai that are great in some areas and terrible in others. (Ai are also too passive in some situations and highly predictable from a diplomatic POV.)-Lack of any form of major diplomatic UI such as color coding alliances, Ai's opinion of other factions, ect.-Too few victory conditions?  (This is more my personal opinion, just look at how many ways you can win in Civ)-Lack of internal/external trading.There are certainly a few more, but I believe these are the major points.All in all, I've put nearly 60 hours into a game that was released just under 2 weeks ago.  The UI is pretty good in most areas, and it was surprisingly easy to pick up when compared to Paradox's other games.  I've thoroughly enjoyed this game so far and I can't wait to see what future updates and expansions are on their way.

												Good game crippled by a bad UI.  A lot of things 4X players would expect to see such as auto-explore options for scout ships weren't even in at launch.  The planet/sector management interface is sorely lacking in sorting options.  There is no interface to view potentially colonizable planets, and the only way to do so is by hovering over the galaxy map looing for green planet icons that disappear if you zoom too far out.That said, the events and race designs are really well done, though the AI seems to balk at the eXpand portion of the 4x genre.  Almost 200 years into a playthrough there were still a LOT of habitable planets on the edge of the galaxy that were sitting uncolonized.  The endgame threats are cool though, and I'm looking forward to what the game will look like in 3-6 months with some TLC centered on the mid game lull and UI shortcomings.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												I've been enjoying Stellaris a lot so far, but I have a few issues with it:+Epic Scale, the largest galaxies can have 1000 Star Systems, each with multiple planets+Beautiful Graphics, the battles look great, weapon effects and sounds are good for the most part+Customization of Species traits, Government, Appearance, Names etc.+Ship design, a very user friendly ship design+Multiple interesting events and locations to explore+Different FTL systems that really change how you play and explore the Galaxy+Long term epic strategy, you can take a species that you discover on a planet from Iron Age tech up to eventually be assimilated into your Empire as an equal member-species (It takes a long time, but I've done it!)-Limit of 5 planets (Initially, can be increased through tech) that you directly manage. You have to create 'sectors' to control more. The AI that manages you sectors really sucks, I had to take a system out of a sector and manage it myself for a while then put it back it as the AI wasn't doing anything I asked it to do. I supplied the sector with plenty of resources to build up those planets within its control.-No tech tree, you get a draw of 3 techs to research (initially, you receive more through exploring and tech upgrades) It makes it hard to plan out what tech you want to research initially, but with further play this might be less of an issue-limited trade with other species, I had a surplus of energy and shortage of minerals, but I couldn't trade away my surplus fast enough to supplement my mineral requirements. The AI usually wants to have a better deal than you are getting otherwise it will reject it. Also, sometimes they won't even trade with you despite you giving them a huge advantage, they still feel insulted that you offered them that deal??-AI for enemies sucks because they all hate you for going for the win conditions. Its really annoying actually.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												Giving this a tentitive yes. I only played through once so probably missed a lot of things my first go around.The good:Basically this is "epic" mode for any other 4x strategy game. It takes a long time to do things and there's usually a lot going on to distract you from your plans. Great depth with good story elements Easy to learn and get started, but lots of depth later on Challenging but not always in a good way - lots of domestic management opportunities but few options to actually control and influence.The BadIt takes away a lot of planning capabilities so you just kind of float around hoping you roll someting good.  No research structure. Random choices appear, but there's not ability to strategically focus on any one area.  Not many levers for when you get in trouble. All micromanagement is forced out of your hands (you can only actively manage 5 planets at a time which tend to become your main sources of income.  Lots of choices but no clear meaning or impact to what you decide. Eventually you just stop caring.  Boring mid-game. You've already outsourced all your planets to your districts to manage, so there's not a lot to do but research and maybe wage war (if you can afford it).Overall 7/10 but could definitely be awesome with a few patched gameplay tweaks

content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												IF you are as old as me, you can appreciate when I say, this game brings me back to the pure joy, and occasionally the frustration, I had when I played the ORIGINAL Sid Meier's Civilization back in 1991 -- that's 25 years ago!I remember playing Civ back then, not realizing how much time had passed, and how how quickly it passed, all because this GAME swept you up in its wonderful 4x mechanics -- and that's what I'm reliving now with Stellaris.  Sure, it's got a few flaws, but between patches and mods, you can fix or tweek just about anything you might find to complain about.So this isn't so much of a technical review, as it's much more of a thank you to Paradox for bringing that feeling back -- bravo, folks, bravo!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												Edit-written on 5/16/2016 some things might be changed for people in the, say it with me, FUTURENote- I've played much less than what is shown. I basicaly never turn my pc off and since I've played this a lot I've left run on in the background for a very long time without playing, like when I'm sleeping sometimes. Anyways-The ai is fairly good. In war, the convintionial fleet warfare it is quite good. However it is quite poor at coordinating with its allies in the sense of not defending the not most powerful ally's territory, but its very good with its allies in the sense of presenting a unified front. It doesn't seem to understand how to fight a war of attrition, and it is horrible at ground combat, attacking and defending. It also struggles with certain alternitive styles of warfare that a player can use like guarlia style, which I've used to great sucess winning the three wars I tried it in where I was reasoniable outmatched and couldn't win in a direct fight. Fleet battles themselves are a bit bugged like if one side fully retreats then no one wins or losses, as far as warscore is concerned. In ai diplomacy it's well done; it's much like EU4. The ai is perphaps not agrressive enough, but I blame that mostly on most alien civs being peaceful kinds of governments. The ai seems to be very good at exsploring. Its seems to be resoniable at managing resource tiles. The  ia isn't agressive enough at colonaision. It is very good at ship design, but almost all the aliens I fought didn't have as many ships as they should of have, but they were mostly federation builders personialies or something similiar. Big bug right now is slavery is broken in the sense that slaves will never revolt. I also found an odd bug in that if you are invading a planet, then in the middle of the battle before can retreat, you end the war and they keep the planet you were attacking your troops will disapear. but the gamewill still think they are the planet so you can always see the planet even though nothing of yours is there. Despite its problems I still say you should play it; most bugs are anoying, but none are game breaking*. * well some are, but they either fix themselves over game time or a reload fixes them. To sumarize at this point its a good grand statagy game, up there with CK2 and EU4, but it is bad 4x game. Its more a 4x lite, grand statagy is the main. I say ignore the victory goals, make your own, its much better that way. Roleplaying in it is very fun like in CK2, however you for the most part don't have to do stupid things for roleplay. Its like EU4, but not as cut throat. Its half of each in space with its own uquine elements with the potentionial to become the best grand statagy. Right I say its the best grand stategy in space, after all there arn't very many, most are mainly 4x.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												The game overall is extremely good, judging by the 113.5 hours I have logged in the first WEEK of the game being released. That being said, you will enjoy this game until you have to declare war on someone. The warscore system is genuinely the worst war system I've ever seen in a 4x game, and I play A LOT of 4x games. The game forces you to create "war goals" which at first glance make sense, until you realize that you can only capture a few PLANETS (not systems) at a time, or form a protectorate over the enemy. You CANNOT just sweep in on a declaration of war and eliminate/capture an entire empire in one swoop. You have to "liberate" or capture three or so at a time, and then accept peace. Wait like 10-20 years, and THEN declare war again, but usually that just turns everyone against you. So for a game that says it gives you the freedom to create whatever kind of empire you want, it's true on that part. But what it fails to deliver on, is allowing you to actually carry that out. If you want to create an empire that is hell-bent on capturing and destroying everyone, you can create that, but once you have to actually begin taking over systems and empires, be ready to break out some painkillers for the massive headache that is the warscore system.Additionally,  most everything else people say is true. The UI can screw you over at times, and if it does it REALLY screws you over, but in my experience that has been very few and far between, if at all. The Federation system to me doesn't totally make sense, since I don't really see the benefit in forming one. (Not in a philosophical sense, but a gameplay sense. I don't see any in-game benefit with forming a federation anyway. Just more reason to pull out the painkillers.To sum this game up, you WILL thoroughly enjoy this. Paradox has yet again created a stellar 4x game that again sets the standard for other companies to live up to. This is the way 4x games should be made. Like I said, I play a lot of 4x, including the complicated micro-managing ultimate 4x simulator Distant Worlds: Universe. This game is just a lot more fun to play. DW: U might be more of the "classic 4x" game, but Stellaris is a game you can jump into every single time and enjoy your playtime. That's a game I'd recommend.

												My wife and I are obsessed with this game.  It is the best space strategy game I've played.  Highly recommend playing this game.  It has a great single player replayability, but it truely shines in multiplayer, especially if you can get a group of friends to continue playing in the same galaxy.The UI is fairly easy to learn and use and does not require memorizing a bunch of hotkeys (though there are a few you can use if that's your thing). You can tailor the settings to make it challenging throughout the game from the first century to the last and beyond.Great game.  Huge thanks to the developers.  Please keep supporting this game and generating new content/updates to it.

												Stellaris is one of the rare games where you truly cannot predict exactly how a given playthrough will go. You may choose the same 'nation', the same traits, species, galaxy shape and size - and yet one game will have you expand at an enormous pace, the next will have you face to face with an overwhelmingly powerful xenophobic curb-stomping force of a neighbour.As with Crusader Kings 2, Paradox has already shown an interest and willingness to adapt and develop Stellaris well beyond its release state. This one is well-worth grabbing, and is a must-buy if you enjoyed CK2.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												An absolutely amazing space 4X game that brings some new twists and life to the genre. Before I go on, know that there are some issues with the game as it is now. Late game ends up a bit lacking, and the interface needs some work. Diplomatic communication and AI needs a small upgrade too. BUT, don't think the game is unplayable if these things worry you. If you pick up this game, my advice to you, is grab your favorite sci-fi, and roleplay it. This game is unprecedented on the feeling it gives you as the leader of your empire. It IS your empire, and it IS your guys that are being badass. It's kinda hard to put it in words, but you are going to end up immersed and that familiar "One more turn" feeling that sucks you down the rabbit hole, will hit you HARD. As it is now, this game is one of my all time favorites, right up there with the classics, and it's only going to get better. Paradox has always had extensive support with updates and fantastic DLC after launch. And you can mod this game with the same fervor you mod Skyrim, just waiting on those total conversion mods, yum. So yes. Recommended with high marks.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2016
												After playing through countless 4X space games trying to re-live the enjoyment of MOO2 as a kid, finally there is a new version of MOO to play. Problem is, I found stellaris while waiting for MOOCTS to become less buggy, and more like MOO2..... and it turns out stellaris everything I've looking for in a 4X space game and more. A Few Things:The game gives you the feel of actually exploring out from your solar system. Surveying feels meaningful and enjoyable with storyline elements and technlogies introduced from discoveries. The choices you make in creating a race have a definite effect on how your empire will grow and what problems you will encounter in your growth.Space battles are enjoyable and actually performed in the same solar system view, in real time, as your empire management. No clunky transition or other players having to wait. Balance of the ship weapons and attributes could be adjusted a bit but I have no real suggestions on how to addequately do so.Technology research feels meaningful, having standard, rare, reverse engineered, and dangerous technologies to choose from, each with there intrinsic benefits and risks is new to me. Technologies seem to impact game mechanics enough to really try and research and aquire/level-up scientists.Having leaders, governors, admirals, and generals is a nice throwback to MOO2. Their benefits, stats, and effects on gameplay make them important and valuable... and dissappointing when they die of old age.AI is enjoyable but could use some work. There are a few quirks that I'm sure are not attributed to be a race actually being programmed to be ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Most of these quirks happen to be odd behavior and responses when trading/treaties/etc., a few others are in the actual war goals management and/or the behavior of attacking fleets during wartime. These minor AI issues do not reduce the enjoyment of the game enough not to buy it though. Buy it. Enjoy it. Enough said.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												After about 6 hours of playtime (Which means playing the "tutoral" to transition early-mid game).This is a pretty slow paced game, and takes a bit of getting used to in the beginning. If you are accustomed to Paradox's titles, that shouldn't be a problem; but if you compare this game directly to similar titles (Endless space, Sins of a solar empire) you will definitely notice that combat is not as highly prioritized here. Definitely is a beautiful game, but not really action packed.About 3 hours into the game, something hard to identify happened that really sparked my interest. Hard to describe, but something pulls me into the game to make sure my invented space race will triumph and succeed.I figure I'll get as much value out of this as Crusader Kings or Europa Universalis, which are some of my most played games on Steam. A good enough feat,I guess.***ADDITION***So, after finishing the first "tutorial campaign" in about 24 hours, I am really starting to fall in love with this game as well. There is definitely enough content here to carry the game through 100 hous of gameplay. It will only get better with the coming DLCs.One superb aspect of the game is the configuration of your starships. It's really fun to spend time in the Ship Designer and try to figure out the perfect combination of Hulls, shields, weapons; all in regard to your Empire bonuses.The combat needs some more work though - as it is now you have too little control of formations and stuff like that. Not unusal for a Paradox game, but in this game you really want to make sure your ship designs fight as intended.All in all, an even stronger recommendation thatn before!

All you have to do is provide military support.Cons:Minor lag spikes but that is to be expectedFinal Score: 9.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												After about 6 hours of playtime (Which means playing the "tutoral" to transition early-mid game).This is a pretty slow paced game, and takes a bit of getting used to in the beginning. If you are accustomed to Paradox's titles, that shouldn't be a problem; but if you compare this game directly to similar titles (Endless space, Sins of a solar empire) you will definitely notice that combat is not as highly prioritized here. Definitely is a beautiful game, but not really action packed.About 3 hours into the game, something hard to identify happened that really sparked my interest. Hard to describe, but something pulls me into the game to make sure my invented space race will triumph and succeed.I figure I'll get as much value out of this as Crusader Kings or Europa Universalis, which are some of my most played games on Steam. A good enough feat,I guess.***ADDITION***So, after finishing the first "tutorial campaign" in about 24 hours, I am really starting to fall in love with this game as well. There is definitely enough content here to carry the game through 100 hous of gameplay. It will only get better with the coming DLCs.One superb aspect of the game is the configuration of your starships. It's really fun to spend time in the Ship Designer and try to figure out the perfect combination of Hulls, shields, weapons; all in regard to your Empire bonuses.The combat needs some more work though - as it is now you have too little control of formations and stuff like that. Not unusal for a Paradox game, but in this game you really want to make sure your ship designs fight as intended.All in all, an even stronger recommendation thatn before!

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												Paradox have outdone themselves.>The customisation for your race, ships, planets etc and the ability to rename practically everything makes it really feel like something to care about or create some hilarious parrot based socialism.>The AI is solid, they will build different kinds of ships, diplomacy is more cautious upon first contact as you'd expect discovering a new space faring species and ethos differences really matter.>The different FTL methods of travel allow for fresh ideas and tactics for expanding and warring in each game.>Different ethos present vastly different challenges in each game- pacifists have to deal with conquered enemy pops because theyre not going to purge them, they have to be friendly and slowly incorporate them into their empire, whilst fanatic militarists might just kill them all (as my friend space hitler did in our multi game)There's 1 or 2 minor bugs as can be expected on release, nothing game alterring though that can't be fixed, and this is paradox- I've come to find this company the most reliable games company especially in this format of grand stategy- Bugs will be fixed, the game play will be alterred slightly and mixed up to freshen up the game every now and then.All in all this game gets 11 singularities out of 10, quite the paradox.

												My friend really rattled me to get this game, Hard. REALLY hard, it was a good thing that he convinced me to get it.If you like a game that involves building an empire and expanding in a universe, chances are this game is for you. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
												TLDR version: It's good in same way as Skyrim... As in fun, but you definitly feel the game is bare-bones and lacking content wise some areas. Buggy as a TES game as well. Mods are what is going to keep this afloat above many other 4x games after the massive hypetrain has left station.Messy Rant section:Game offers you 6 city and 6 ship looks for each race category. Good chance all mammals fly the same design and all fungals fly their type. Cities seen in tiny window is a nice thouch, kinda a vague reminder from old Heroes turn based strategy games, would love to see more alternatives... As in ship design, you can easy design ship weapons etc. equipment. Ship combat is equally simplistic, as in order attack commando and that's it, with possible emergency ftl retreat (seriously damages ships). I like. However the styling of said ships gets blown so far out of the water and into unknown Blorg space in comparison to Galactic Civilizations III ship design. Only limit there is your imagination. Guess Paradox want to grind out our pockets for more options here in future. Offtopic- Gief endgame crisis there the GC 3 Crusade comes to cleanse the galaxy if there is no human empires alive or free? And what happen to slave uprising?Traits for your races are seriously limited in options. A lesser degree with flags and symbols. In first vanilla game I had difficulties seeing what faction owned what. I was orange and so was my vassal and 2 of my neighbours. Thankfully partly fixed by mods now.While talking about my vanilla game with no mods, I got no achievements. However I don't care about that, but thought I should mention it anyway.Mod menu is permanently bugged out, as in dropdown list over categories are stuck over the mod listing. Really annoying. (Validated the game files twice, not really into reinstalling yet)AI, is really♥♥♥♥♥♥atm. like in most 4x games. Hope you like getting spammed by sharing Star Charts, typically if you have explored more than them (might be random how good that trade is though). Classic strategy of 4x games, Diplomacy = spammed by worthless deals by ai. (Civ 5 and embassy requests trauma)You will have puny vassals hating your guts and being disloyal when they are no position to break free (cud not bribe them with energy or minerals either for more love). Pretty certain only reason they survived at all was because of me shielding them from other empires.Your AI controlled sectors will be poorly optimized, feeling the need for mods to ignore the sector use completely. Examples I saw over 20 systems. Research sector building energy over research yields, food over energy yields and research right next to capital building over food yields? Sectors also have no way of earning or getting influence to build or upgrade buildings? Also miss a balanced optimization plan on sector overview, as it builds what is best and try to avoid overflow of food when a planet is full on population. For you see, paradox don't believe in trade between planets. :pTech and traits for getting back resources from sectors should also be a thing. Lots of tech options, which is good for the random tech tree is a blessing against cookie cutter spec. Problem is that most extra weapon techs from early aliens don't really stand out compared to default weapon techs, as in ignorable, except the ones that unlock a decent armor. From what I have heard there is also an ungodly amount of ground combat forces even if the game is generally simplistic in that regard, as in send fleet, bomb planet (planet can't do anything about orbital bombardment, no Indepence Day heroics here) and drop bog standard troops and planet fall easy. Some things feel missing like trade between planets in your control and outside. No options for colonizing either through tech, perk or planet specialization of toxic, volcanic and barren planets?Disconnect between events and what is really happing with aliens under your command: I decided to infiltrate a primitive government. And it was success. Event screen told me these aliens was overjoyed to join my empire and praised me as lord saviour Gaben etc. Great I thought, finally I have alien friends that don't hate me as part of main group in my Commonwealth of Man (human space baddies). Yet when I saw their planet afterwards, they were hating me more than any other alien race in galaxy. Quite the achievement. Some of it is because different ethos… Yet it's ridiculous considering what I done to rest of the galaxy regarding aliens listing, but not limited to: raiding, pillaging, brutal wars against peaceful populations, enslavement of an unholy number of alien subjects and purging dozen worlds (at least 1 species forever gone) over countless systems. So my new alien friends had to get a lesson instantly, even if they had endured none of the hardships for throwing away a future on top. Lesson being; friendship is mandatory and resistance is impolite.

The game feels alive.Highly recommended.

content:

												I was a bit iffy about buying this game, as I've tried some other Paradox games, and just had a hard time getting into the complexity of them.  I wanted a more complex Civ, but not to the point of EU.  Stellaris really did that for me.  I write this review at about 60 hours and I'm not bored yet.  I have really enjoyed the game play so far, the variety of playstyles and races, etc.There are some points in the game that I would fix, but so far I think Paradox has been very responsive with their attempt to fix any bugs, and I have high hopes about them fixing some of the gameplay issues that I have run into (federation issues, diplomacy, etc.) considering how much I have seen them responding around Reddit and their forums.  Allowing mods is also a great thing for any game to do, in my opinion.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
 GRAND STRATEGY ON A GALACTIC SCALE Stellaris is the game. A really good and great game, but it could be better. Customizing your empire is incredible, can customize to the smallest detail. Graphically not stand out, but it is not important here. The music is superb. The art of the game is great. Menus, interface... all polished. Has the Paradox touch, all the greatness of the 4x mixed with a real time strategic, very complex and fun. The problem here is that the game is unable to maintain that illusion, especially in the mid-game and at the end we have a game halfway between 4x and RTS, unfinished, giving that feeling of greatness, you have a lot to do, but without the depth you want.Things like diplomacy or trade has a important lack of depth for the moment (improvements announced). And the galaxy could look more live. I also think, even having an exaggerated number of skins, are too similar sometimes (need robots!)... many skins but you got pretty more different races on Endless Space for example. The governors, leaders, captains... looks too similar. There are things that are already there and I can see it is not what it should be. The game is great and awesome like I said before, don't misunderstand me, but is a Paradox game, so it can be more better. Sure, the paths will come, the DLC will expand the game and it will turn the game into something huge... but not for now, I would have liked more content in the release date.Said all this, the updates policy that have announced promises to transform the game in the best and biggest space-themed game 4x ever made, I can see it now, but with time... this game will be an strategic masterpiece.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												Having never played any of paradox' other games, or any grand strategy for that matter, I do find the game fun and surprisingly accessible.Gud:-Incredible sense of scale. Initially the galaxy seems impossibly large, and then latter almost confining as your empire expands.-Tech researching system: there are 3 categories of research that each have their own name, which I dont remember at all. Instead, I recognize them by their colors. There's Blue, which seems to have things like lasers, shields, drives, and sensor upgrades. Green, which has tech focused on developing planets, borders, governments, and armies. And then Yellow: missiles and rail guns and probably some other stuff. All 3 color tech lines get to be researched simultaneously. Presumably to keep things interesting, picking a tech to research is something of a lottery. You can only pick from the available 3-4(usually) techs to research, and it randomly changes everytime.-Empire creation system. Tons of options. You wont know what any of them mean for a long while, but that's ok. Just dive in and you'll figure it out.-Music is gud.-Graphix gud too, except for occasional issues.-"Fallen Empires" add an interesting twist to games. A fallen empire is basically a near maxed out empire tech-wise and fleet-wise. Each one has a different trigger that will cause them to come out of seclusion and butt♥♥♥♥ the offender. Essentially, they add random rules to games, including "dont touch their borders", "don't enslave other dudes", "don't randomly violate a percieved holy site(?)" and others.-random story missions/events. These are a lot of fun. Too bad they seem to stop popping up in the late game.Not gud:-Some graphcial problems in the late game with very very large fleets not animating properly, which is kinda sad. Watching the space battles is one of the coolest parts of the game.-Trade UI is a little lacking. Would especially like to see the "what would make this deal work?" button from galciv.-Strangely missing features. What is probably the most disppointing thing about stellaris is not whats in it, but what isn't. Here's a non-exhaustive list of things one would expect to find in a game like this, but won't:*Trade routes. Completely missing. All trade is done through trade deals, no caravan/tradeship routes.*Espionage. The closest I coudl find is the ability to bribe or suppress seperatist factions. Otherwise, completely absent.*Religions. This one is especially strange as you can pick for your empire to be religious.*Varried victory conditions. Unless I'm missing something, the only 2 possible win scenarios are owning 40%+ of the galaxy or otherwise wiping out every other empire. While I'm not really a fan of the "cultural" victories from civ games, I think it wouldn't hurt to have other options for winning.So all in all, a very fun game. The biggest flaws are ones of omission. What's there right now is qutie solid and polished for the most part.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												VerdictIf you liked Playing Hearts of Iron or Europa Universe. Then yes it is for you. Same mechanics but space theme. The game is less complicated then Hearts of Iron or Europa. Non-less it is complicated from average RTS game you play. That is why it is called Grand Strategy game. The game become addictive once you start to learn its mechanics. Each game session days long. You can shorten it by decreasing the number of Star and NPC empires. But where is fun in that.  There is many ways you can play the game. Go all-out war with every nation you meet or find a diplomatic way to crush them all. Game can be improved is some aspects. Like tool tips are missing on crucial information. Although it is access able by this can be done the easy way. I am sure it will be fixed in next upcoming patches.

												I would give this game a tentative recommendation.I have enjoyed my playtime so far for the most part, not plagued with performance issues, though a few bugs. The game as it stands is a flawed gem, lots of things are done right, but a lot of things are also not fully fleshed out. I appreciate that a lot of things are on the way to being fixed and added, but that's not a great basis on which to release your "finished product".However, despite it's edges and sharp corners where ergonomics is desperately needed to streamline the interface and interactions with your empire, it's still a worthwhile buy. In time the purchase will become more and more worthwhile hopefully.So I recommend it's purchase, but don't expect the game to be firing on all cylinders right now as some game mechanics like trade and "sectors" need work.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												I had never imagined that Stellaris would be such a great game. Having played other Paradox games such as Europa Universalis 4, Crusader Kings 2 and Victoria 2, I had expected a very intricated and complex game in terms of strategy, but Stellaris has accomplished much more than this. Firstly, Paradox managed to get the genre perfectly. Being a Star Trek fan, I can say that there are inumerous features that are very resembling to the world of the original series. The game, however, does not restrict itself to Star Trek and there are references to various other classical features of the genre. Regarding the other Paradox games, I feel that in Stellaris war is not so important and it in peace that you wil play most hours of the game (specially at the first decades). Of course, being a mix of grand strategy and 4X, Stellaris was expected to have  some exploration  mechanics, but Stellaris also have loads of ways to develop your empire at peace. Moreover, the complexity of the mechanics are fantastic. They are in no way difficult to learn and it is very fun to manage the social and political aspects of your empire. The empire creator is also amazing with a lot of different governments to choose in addition to ethics and general characteristics of your people. The AI empires react to your presence mainly according to their and your ideology which makes for very funny games. Finally, the UI is a thousand times more accessible than in past Paradox games and the tutorial does a good job, which in my view makes the game not so difficult to learn to newcomers to the grand strategy genre.

content:
Posted: April 1
												This is a great game, and mods turn it into a fantastic game. It brings Paradox's brand of grand strategy to space, and has turned out rather well. It has all the feeling of immersion of Paradox's historical titles, but is even more of a sandbox without any of the baggage of having to pay lip service to historical accuracy. It is well worth picking up during a sale, especially with major expos.Like all Paradox titles: it isn't a simple game, but is easy to get into if you are willing to just sit down and learn the rules of the game.Perhaps the biggest plus point of this game is the sandbox it provides. You have a great deal of choice when it comes to how to design your empire/species/military/government; and that's before you start, to say nothing about what happens during the course of a game. Recent updates and workshop mods greatly expand upon this. Whether you're the competitive type who wants to squeeze every last advantage he can in multiplayer, or the roleplayer who wants to replicate species from his favourite sci-fi franchises, there is something for you.Variation. Every game will involve some degree of exploration, colonisation, wars of conquest, strategic interventions, diplomacy, and tech/arms race. There is almost always something to do. There are tons of random events and strange systems you can stumble into while playing.Combat. Admittedly, armies and planetary invasions are rarely interesting, but this IS a space game. Fleet battles and movements are some of the most intense moments of the game, and fleet composition and formation can mean the difference between winning the war and watching your ships get annihilated.Multiplayer. This game is great on its own, but like pretty much all strategy games, playing with and against humans is where it truly shines. Additionally, I've noticed far less OOS problems with this game than certain other Paradox titles.There are of course still issues. While performance has greatly improved since initial release, it's still an issue as it is with all Paradox titles. The AI isn't too bright, and though it can be fun to play against for a couple of games, you'll want to play more multiplayer after singleplayer becomes too predictable. Some of the gameplay design decisions have been questionable, but fortunately on this point Paradox has thus far been excellent about listening to player feedback and is releasing updates to address them.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11
												This is an awesome game.  As an old Masters of Orion addict,  this is MOO on steroids.  The things I love about this game are 1) the huge number of star systems to explore, 2) an incredible number of technologies to research, 2) easy colonization from a list of eligible worlds, 3) colonies to manage, 4) interesting anomalies to research while exploring, 5) huge space battles, 5) dozens of other races to interact with, 6) an option to design your own race, and 7) ship design.    The downside to a long complex game is that it is very slow.  You can pause it at any time, and you can set the speed for passage of time from very slow to very fast.  I run it at very fast, about a day every 1/2 second, and it's still a long game.  In fact, I have yet to finish a game after 150+ hours of playing.  I admit that I stop a game when I run out of room to explore and expand.  The victory condition to control 40% of the habitable planets is a daunting goal in a galaxy of 600 star systems and around 50 races.  But I don't mind not playing a game to the end.  I like the early part of the game where you explore new worlds, find neat anomalies, and colonize worlds.The space battles are cool, but essentially, the strongest fleet wins.  There really are no strategic or tactical options for you to pick that give a less powerful fleet a chance to win against a stonger foe.  It's possible that I just haven't found (or researched) them yet, but the standard ship tactics are Corvettes charge in and get destroyed, Destroyers and Cruisers are intermediate, while Battleships stand back and shoot the big guns/beams/missiles.      The things I could do without to make the game less complex are political factions (dealing with unruly populations is a pain), and the very low number of colonized worlds you can control (starts with 5, research adds a few more).  You do get to assign excess colonies to new sectors, which manage themselves.     I really appreciate that Stellaris is very player-friendly.  It provides information, explanation, and feedback.  If you try to do something you can't do, it will tell you WHY you can't do it.  For example, if you send a scientist to survey an anomoly, and then forget and send another scientist to do the same thing, it tells you that a scientist is already doing it.  If you try to declare war on someone when you can't (like having a non-agression  agreement in place), it informs you why.  If you can't upgrade a building, it will tell you the reason you can't upgrade it (need tech or some pre-requisite).  As a player, I appreciate knowing why things don't work or can't be done.    If you like large, complex space game with a lot of options and interesting events, I recommend this game highly.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												Stellaris is a game where you colonize and conquer the galaxy with interstellar travel, research, and war. In short, it's a mixture between a typical Paradox game like Europa Universalis IV and a Civilization game -- it's probably what Civilization: Beyond Earth should have been.In my first game, I was able to make a fanatical spiritualist and somewhat collectivist society with a divine mandate, which I termed the Papal State, and which was led by Pope Francis III. I colonized several planets, killed some space pirates, and found out we're not alone in the universe. It's a very interesting game, and though I'm generally not a fan of science fiction, I would recommend it.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												the tl;dr is that you need to play this game if you like si-fi or grand strategy or if you have a big imagination and you need an excuse to dissapear from the face of the earth for 100+ hoursthe longer version of that is that this game is fantastic. My biggest reason for loving it is that it appeals so well to my desire to roleplay. After 500 hours it's still surprisingly difficult to find yourself in the exact same situation that you've been in before. There's just enough RNG right now that you can go from being a martial dictatorship that ends up granting large liberties to its people and forms a federation with several large powers, including an ancient fallen empire and in your next game end up with a scientific republic fighting against overwhelming odds as they become trapped within their borders by two spiteful empires. For some people the game will seem shallow, but the imagination of this game is what truly makes the experience memorable. Things like what I described above are things you may never experience and you'll end up with a whole different story, like being a genocide-obsessed demon race that teams up with xenophilic monkeys to prevent a god-like empire from overwhelming the galaxy.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												With update 1.2.4 out:Pros:-Early game is fantastic!-Exploration of the galaxy is fun.-The tutorial is very well implemented and actually really useful and good. This is a first for a Paradox game that I've seen.-The war goals -system, which is a Paradox norm, works surprisingly well in a 4x game.-Ship design is well-implemented and fun.Cons:-Mid game onwards there is not much to do at the moment. Only 2 victory conditions to strive to (conquest & domination) makes it seem more like a really polished beta than an actual fleshed out and completed game right now. Knowing Paradox this'll change in the future with various patched, dlc and expansions.-Research point saving/accumulating does not work correctly with regards to back-to-back special projects. This with being forced to have the AI run the majority of your empire (you can only directly control 5+ star systems in a galaxy of 400, 600, 800  etc. systems) makes it so you are forced to play "enjoy the ride" instead of "the optimal way".-Diplomacy is very limited. This is paired with very, very repetitive and limited AI empire leader personalities makes for a dull system. Well, atleast it works fine with the only possible victory conditions so there's that. -Limited tactical possibilities in space combat, non-existent in ground combat/planet invasions.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												EDIT: I nominated this for the "Just 5 More Minutes" award. This game truly does eat your time. Just see my playtime so far.TL:DR - If you like space 4X games, this gives Master of Orion 2016 (what I'd call a gold standard) a run for it's money.What I liked about the game - Once I understood the resource system, the game is great. In the start of a play session, it really makes you think about how you're going to expand. For being a "real time with a pause button" system, I feel the gameplay is actually slower pace than Turn Based Master of Orion, which can escalate very quickly if you know what you're doing. And the race generation system really lets you fine tune your playstyle with the mix of Ethos, Governments, and race bonuses. And these choices help determine what space empires you'll be friendly with as you progress through the game. The diplomacy is also decent, with many strategic options in building negotiations.Also of note, the mod community for this game is awesome and any "bugs" or issues you might have with the playstyle have been tweaked by the community. So that's a big plus.And for a game that doesn't have much in the way of "story", in my big 1000 star 100+hour playthrough it's not hard for a lot of personal narratives to play out between AI sessions thanks to how diplomacy works. That nation you didn't get along with will start warming to you when you start war with their long term rivals. And "End Game" events make things even more interesting.And call me crazy, but I believe that "Paradox" is a trustworthy name in the game industry. Maybe some of their games are "DLC laden", but the positive is that they support their games for years and I could see this series being supported for some time. And at a price that's under what a normal AAA game will cost you, I believe this game has a lot of value at the $40 price point and below. And even though at time of writing this I'm +140hrs in, I could see myself easily logging 1000+ hours into this as I already have future playthroughs planned. I've bought a ALOT of games. But this one definately keeps my attention like few others do.What could use some work - I think the space combat could use a bit more polish. I wish it was more tactical. But supposedly that's even being addressed in a future patch.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												>Short Version: Stellaris is pretty much what you'd get if Master of Orion II and Spore had a baby. That's right, friggin SPORE with its absurdly vast galaxy inhabited by hundreds of procedurally generated spacefaring civilzations with a wide diversity of philosophies and personalities that determine how they interact with the player and eachother (and just like Spore there are also pre-spaceflight races that you can interact with). After installing the game I spent a good 5 hours in the empire editor creating dozens of customized alien civilizations to fill my games with.- Overall a very solid 4x space game that I would recommed to any fan of the the 4x space genre - (only during a Steam Sale, of course; I make a personal point of never buying anything over $20 at full price on Steam) - However, if you're a Paradox fan looking for EU4 or CK2 but IN SPAAAAAACE!!!, this ain't it. <<DISCLAIMER>>: Stellaris is not truely as vast in scale as Spore and is only absurdly huge by traditional 4x space standards: the maximum galaxy size in Stellaris is 1,000 solar systems vs Spore's mind-boggling 500,000 solar systems, and whereas the number of potential empires in Spore feels pretty much limitless, the maximum number of AI empires you can set in Stellaris is 39 for a maximum sized galaxy.<<DOUBLE DISCLAIMER>>: This number does not include pre-FTL spaceflight civs, pre-sentient upliftable races, the precurser Fallen empires, or additional empires formed from liberated/rebelling worlds, so there can be more than just 39 other empires in the galaxy as the game progresses.>Long Version: <AKA Rant, AKA TL;DR>Once again, this game is NOT Europa Universalis! Off of the top of my head there are only three main things that Stellaris and EU4 have in common that aren't ubiquitous to the 4x genre in general:- There IS an Ironman mode, and you need to have it enabled to earn achievements. (Hillariously I didn't notice I wasn't earning any achievements until I was 40 hours into my first run)- A wargoal/warscore%/demands warfare system similar to EU4, except you don't need CBs, both the attacker and defender can choose multiple wargoals, and the demands you make during peace deals must be chosen from the wargoals you laid out at the start of the war.- You might never actually "complete" a playthrough from start to finish due to the absurd length of the game: In EU4 you'll probably become unstoppable long before 1821 and get bored with world conquest; in Stellaris there's no time limit and there's an entire friggin GALAXY to conquer!In other words...If you go into Stellaris expecting a fully-pached version of EU4 set in outer space, complete with a realistically overly-complicated global economy with trade goods/trade routes/trade power/piracy, insane amounts of micro-management or sectors that work like Cossack-esque estates, in-depth religious wars with fleshed-out religions, random events and disastors that can turn your empire upside-down, and all that other good stuff - you're going to be sorely disappointed. > If you're expecting a straightforward 4x space game along the lines of Endless Space or Galactic Civilizations, you'll be pleasantly surprised by what Stellaris DOES has to offer: - gameplay on a truely galactic scale, ala Spore- an incredible diversity of possible alien races with uncountable combinations of ratial traits, climate preferences, philosophies, and government types (again, similar to Spore)- 90+ species avatars across 6 phenotypes (mammalian, reptilian, avian, arthropod, molluscoid, and fungoid)- 20+ distinct AI personalites, determined by an empire's traits, ethos, and government type.(this game really does have a lot in common with Spore's space stage; just take away the spice-trading economy, and toss in more conventional space 4x features, like a tech tree, space stations, space whales, and massive fleets with adjustable loadouts)- the ability to study, infiltrate, and/or uplift pre-ftl civilizations- the ability to genetically modify individual populations to change their traits and climate preferences, or grant intelligence to pre-sentient lifeforms so they can join your empire.- complex diplomacy that includes just about every option I've seen in the 4x genre: NAPs, mutual defense pacts, alliances, federations, protectorates, vassalization, tributaries, guaranteeing/supporting independance, research agreements and open migration treaties.- slavery, forced relocation and ethnic cleansing of indivual populations on planet tiles- policies that determine an empire's stance on ethical matters such as slavery, forced relocation, and ethnic cleansing.(you can outright outlaw these things and force other empires to do the same via wargoals)- a unique card-based research system can can only be described by the wiki: http://www.stellariswiki.com/Technology- EVERYTHING that gets destroyed in outer space leaves behind salvage that can be studied and possibly reverse-engineered by science ships for extra research opportunities (this includes random alien encounters like space whales and giant space amoebas) - SECTORS: love 'em or hate 'em, here's a link with tips on how to deal with them:https://www.reddit.com/r/Stellaris/comments/4j0sm6/sector_tips/(info might be somewhat dated due to patches and bugfixes)- varying means of FTL travel ala Sword of the Stars / Star Ruler- More si-fi referances than you can shake a lightsaber at: http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/ShoutOut/StellarisOn the flop side, there are also some features you would probably expect from the 4x-space genre that are noticably absent: - There's no trade economy AT ALL. You can trade resources with other empires by putting energy credits, minerals, and strategic resources on the table during diplomatic trade agreements, but there's nothing in this game akin to trade routes, space freighters, or trade stations. - No trading for individual technologies between empires. You can reverse engineer their tech, but you can't trade for it. - Stellaris has a food resource for growing populations, but surplus food cannot be shared between colonies (probably because there aren't any trade routes or freighters to move the food with, which is pretty funny in hindsight).- No diplomatic or science victory conditions. Personally, I think Paradox took the whole 4x thing a little too literrally. The only victory options are Conquest (conquer or subjugate all other civilizations) and Domination (own 40% of all inhabitable planets in the galaxy) In other words, once you get past the Exploration, Expansion, and Explotation phases, you're pretty much stuck with Extermination; there's nothing even close to resembling a science victory and the closest thing you can get to a diplomatic victory is via vassalizing and/or integrating everyone else. In all fairness to the negative reviews, I can see how the whole "conquer a hundred empires and take over thousands of planets" thing with long truces between wars of aggression can get tediously repetitive, especially if the remaining empires get boiled down to two super-power federations slugging it out once every election cycle. Again, one of the only things Stellaris has in common with EU4 is that you can reach a point where you're unbeatably strong, but are still forced to spend an inordinate amount of time playing through to the end if you actually want to "achieve victory." There's a reason why Paradox didn't create a Steam achievement for actually beating this game. That rant might have ended on a low note, but I still give Stellaris a solid positive review. Paradox has done a great job of resolving most of the bugs and issues in a (mostly) timely fastion, and so far all of the new non-cosmetic features have been patched in completely free of charge, resulting an a decently polished and thoroughly enjoyable game.
