content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												After a short amount of playtime, I'd like to offer my impressions of this game and why I recommend it - for people that will enjoy a game of this type.I have always had difficulty with Paradox games because I get to a point with all I have to learn and I go "screw it, I'm gonna play CS:GO".  While I enjoy strategy games (a long time Civ player), Paradox games have always been on another level.  Usually when you read user reviews for games like Europa Universalis, you'll often see a comment about the learning curve.What I enjoy about Stellaris is that, while there still is a learning curve, Stellaris is more inviting that other Paradox games, while still maintaining it's depth.As far as commenting on the other aspect of the game, I'll be, in fairness, general due to the amount of time that I have played/the game has been released.  This game borrows from a few different space strategy games that I have played, such as Galactic CIvilizations, and puts them together quite nicely.Lastly, as a final comment: I usually distain the ship design portion of space strategy games.  They have always been bulky and sort of difficult to manage sometimes.  Stellaris does it right.  You can customize your modules as you wish, or if you do not have any interest in this, there is a button that will simply press the best modules available so you don't have to worry about it.  But, if you do want to worry about it, you can, to your heart's content.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												Stellaris is a game where you colonize and conquer the galaxy with interstellar travel, research, and war. In short, it's a mixture between a typical Paradox game like Europa Universalis IV and a Civilization game -- it's probably what Civilization: Beyond Earth should have been.In my first game, I was able to make a fanatical spiritualist and somewhat collectivist society with a divine mandate, which I termed the Papal State, and which was led by Pope Francis III. I colonized several planets, killed some space pirates, and found out we're not alone in the universe. It's a very interesting game, and though I'm generally not a fan of science fiction, I would recommend it.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
												the tl;dr is that you need to play this game if you like si-fi or grand strategy or if you have a big imagination and you need an excuse to dissapear from the face of the earth for 100+ hoursthe longer version of that is that this game is fantastic. My biggest reason for loving it is that it appeals so well to my desire to roleplay. After 500 hours it's still surprisingly difficult to find yourself in the exact same situation that you've been in before. There's just enough RNG right now that you can go from being a martial dictatorship that ends up granting large liberties to its people and forms a federation with several large powers, including an ancient fallen empire and in your next game end up with a scientific republic fighting against overwhelming odds as they become trapped within their borders by two spiteful empires. For some people the game will seem shallow, but the imagination of this game is what truly makes the experience memorable. Things like what I described above are things you may never experience and you'll end up with a whole different story, like being a genocide-obsessed demon race that teams up with xenophilic monkeys to prevent a god-like empire from overwhelming the galaxy.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												let me share you the story of Karl Wolf, President of the United Human Space Republic, elected over (approx.) 15+20 times this guy would just not die. My first ruler, Octavian I ony lasted one term then promptly keeled over and died, however President Wolf even through cycles where he lost support, continuallly got elected just after 1 term of a different president. Eventually I got tired to spending any influence, and Wolf became reelected 9 more times. When I saw that he was the ripe old age of 93 I told myself this dude has to go, he's going to keel over and die any minute so I supported a new candidate the next election. Note, in my republic scientists and governors alike had to my knowlege never made it into their 90's even with the longevity perk.Lo and behold, old age isn't going to keep this guy from the presidency so after 1 term from the new president I thought he had already died. I made a critical mistake of not monitoring the election, and the next time I looked old Karl Wolf was back at it again at the age of 97. At this point I was amazed, so I just let him rule with no interference and he made it through 2 more elections before he finally clocked out at an insane 108 years of age.I highly recommend this game, people will talk about the games mechanics (Honestly, they're great) and all that in other reviews but I actually wanted to share the story of my eternal president. He oversaw the republic rise from a tiny 1 planet system to the juggernaught that had almost 200 pops, through war and peace, and didn't stop overseeing it until he died in office.I'm only 16 hours in at the time of writing this and this is the kind of story I can write about this game.

content:
Posted: February 19
												Age of Wonders 3, Endless Legend, EU, CK 2, The many Civs; I've played and loved them all for slightly different reasons. And I can say Stellaris sits comfortably amongst this group as the sort of game you think about when you're travelling to work, when you're watching TV, When your wife is asking if you put the rubbish out. It's a game with so many layers and so much to do. Sure it has some faults - a paucity of events in the mid-game, lots of busy work, but these pale compared to the epic sweep and constant allusions to concepts created by the great sci-fi authors after which the updates are named. It's like a beautiful woman with slightly buck teeth - look for the good, don't worry about perfection, take her home!!

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												I want to say "EU IV in space" but it's definitely a different flavour despite the fairly familiar gameplay. It keeps most of the complexity, without feeling simplified.For those not overly familiar with Europa Universalis, Stellaris is definitely top-of-the-class along with Endless Space as the ultimate 4x space game (eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, eXterminate).Fairly easy to get the hang of, there's lots to master and lots of different ways to play - and this combined with the traditionally fantastic mod support that comes with Paradox titles means Stellaris will live a long and well-worn life in my library.If you like space, and you like grand strategy, then you'll definitely like this. Fair warning though - I probably can't recommend it to someone who can never game for more than an hour at a time.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												This isn't your normal 4X... This is advanced 4X.It took me awhile to get the hang of this game, and truth be told, I still am. Despite that, though, it's a very enjoyable game! I've had about three playthroughs so far, and it never gets old. My only complaint is that diplomacy can get a bit... Boring. That, and war. I wish there was a bit of variety in this! Again, despite all that, this game is pretty great. The race creator is fun, the music is great, and the graphics are pretty stellar. Pardon the pun. One of my favorite things to do is create a massive empire, create stability in the galaxy, and then throw that all away and watch as the galaxy crumbles. Sure, it is pretty cruel, but it's fun to study the political structure 10, 20, or even 150 years after your empire has collapsed! This game offers a ton of diversity and variety, but it still lacks in some areas. I'd give it a 7/10.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
Surprisingly complex set of features and mechanics that feels polished  , satisfying and fulfilling on release. The framework is set for proceeding additions.Update: As predicted previously this game only gets better as more mechanics are fleshed out throughout the game.While I do have to admit that I have not played the late game as I keep restarting games to optimize my early and mid-game starts. I would like to share my thoughts on Stellaris so far.It is easily apparent that Paradox have put a lot of work to create a framework that consists of different modules and mechanics, from a development perspective this should allow Paradox to easily add more to the game when it comes to complexity and tuning(not that there are any major issues at the moment).A lot of people are complaining about mid-game being stale, I do not find this to be the case. Once the mid-game comes along I find myself trying to maximize naval capacity and have a fleet that is nearing that cap, being Militarist I put it to use. Wars are fast and furious, while it is not just about your naval fleet but also paying attention to your defensive and offensive armies. While I do admit that the AI is horrible some folks are already trying to optimize it via the LUA files and with some work from Paradox it is easily fixable more intelligence is added via IF-THEN statements.In the current state the game plays fantastic, early game is fantastic and you will find yourself addicted to surveying systems to find high resource stations and decent planets and you will shout in glee once you find that 20+ Gaia planet. At normal speed there is plenty of tasks and micromanagement to keep your hands full at every second (day in the game) of every moment. Up the speed to Fast and you will have your hands full.From a multiplayer aspect there are folks whining about corvette rushes, while this is an issue it is easily fixable by boosting the military power of stations and spaceports so that early corvette rushes get thwarted. I am sure there are others with even better solutions. Other than that MP is fantastic, I have been playing in the Stellaris MP steam group(shameless shoutout) and matches with 12+ players are running smoothly. Having this many players in a game along with 15AI to add some action to the early game gives the galaxy a feeling that it is very alive. The salt,politics and drama in voice chat are satisfying while everybody starts to fight over optimal planets/resources and federations begin to form.While upkeep costs exist they do not hinder your science output if you keep your energy credits above 0, you can still sim city while being aggressive in the galaxy. Small things like research alternatives give an addictive randomness to the game and you will find yourself swearing at RNGJesus when you don't get that specific tech you needed.This game is extremely satisfying and provides the excitement and adrenaline that so many other games in the sea of 4x/Grand Strategy do not provide. In the coming months and years I can see this game molding into one of the staples of the genre.Issues that need to be fixed:- MP balance issues (corvettes evasion is overpowered, worm hole is superior in relation to other initial FTL tech , Energy weapons generally outclass missles and kinetic weaponry)- Spaceport , mining bases and early game defense is weak causing early rushes to be a problem- Peace mechanics can be abused to stop players from joining a federation- Number of planets does not scale well with science output (2% increase for every planet) , and there is no way to remediate this causing issues for Wide empires.Nominated: For Test of Time award

												THE best grand strategy game i have ever played by far. The few problems i had with the game design have been patched and it is fantastic. You can start out slow to learn the game at your own pace then speed it up significantly once you know what you're doing. Some of the in-game random events and discoveries can get a tad repetitive, but you can quickly dismiss them without delay so that is a very minor issue since the real meat of the game is exploration and interacting with the other major powers. The only thing this game seems to be missing are subterfuge options such as spying and assassination. If you can afford the price tag, i consider this a must buy.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												I desperately want to change my review to "Recommend," but in its current state (7/10/2016, ver. 1.2.1) Stellaris is one gigantic cocktease of a 4x game. I have played through the game four times, but cannot bring myself to continue the most recent playthrough. Quite simply, the time required to play a single game is not proportionate with how basic a lot of the systems are: from combat to colonization to diplomacy to trade to research, everything feels like a placeholder for a more complex version of itself. If I'm going to sink 20+ hours into a single playthrough, I should be discovering and struggling with new things the whole way through, but once I reach the midgame the game basically plays itself: build auto-designed battleships, colonize my planets, divide into sectors, upgrade my buildings, declare war to slowly chew away at my neighbors, and eventually kill the endgame menace (which is not guaranteed to show up). The game is exciting at the beginning but never expands its mechanics to match its scale.Maybe Paradox will release patches/DLC to flesh out all of these systems, but as it is the game ends up playing in a very straightforward manner that is disappointing given the scope. For example, Sins of the Solar Empire had a more engaging lategame due to multiple win cons and competitive enemies. As it is, even playing Stellaris as a sandbox is boring because of bland enemy interactions (trade or declare war, that's about it).As it is, I'll fire it up again when it receives a major patch/DLC, or when a full-conversion 40k mod exists, at which point I'll re-evaluate my review. Until then, I would recommend that people wait on this game.

												This is my first review, and I thought I'd throw my 2 cents in as the reviews seem to be mixed on both main forums of paradox and here. The game its self is O.K. I can't praise it as I would like, but then again I can't really be too negative about it. The game, as all games these days when released, have to have a bit of work done to them to smooth the bumps etc and Stellaris is no different.The potential seems very high, and I no doubt that it will reach it over time. But, for now, the game for me is seriously lacking in content - especially mid game and it becomes more of a chore than an enjoyment. There are also quite a few bugs, but paradox aren't wasting too much time getting around to them and their next major patch seems to tackle alot of the issues that exist as well as improving the content and meta of the game.It's definitely one of those that you have to take a chance on and I will be eagerly waiting in anticipation for how the game turns out and the journeys it will take me on trying to explore all it's possibilities.Do your research, and watch those vids that are hugely available that will show you the games environment and situation currently.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												Stellaris is a game with a lot of potential. The late-game crises, even with a lack of variety, are particularly amazing. It's a 4X geared for atmosphere rather than competitive balance. What's lacking is a lot of mid-game content and flavour. Wars after the early game are pretty boring because it's inevitably one huge battle where if you win it's slowly bombarding and invading planets one by one. There is no meaningful diplomacy or espionage and no real relationships between the AI other than alliance blocs. The tech tree is neat but after 1 playthrough you'll have seen almost everything which is a real shame given the breadth of SCI-FI available. It doesn't just feel like you're choosing a tech path. The laser/kinetic/missile balance also still needs work.  That said there's a very strong modding community and Paradox will continue to pump out partially free DLC. I'd buy it if you can justify having 1 or 2 playthroughs and coming back in 6 months when a couple of patches are out or if you're willing to heavily mod it/

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												If you like grand strategy in a sci-fi setting then Stellaris is calling! It has a lot of customization for factions (genetic traits, ethical preferences, goverrnment type and policies) and plenty of in game features to explore (robot populations and giving them rights or having them rebel, uplifting pre-sentient species, fallen empires).The galaxy maps are ridiculously huge, the tiny map has over 100+ star systems which each have multiple planets or other objects in them. The game has you exploring them with Enterprise like science ships that require leaders to be successful. There are also a number of natural phenomena and space liforms that keep things exciting.The tech-tree is pretty straight forward divided into three branches of physics, social/biological, and engineering. Ships are designable or you can have the computer make basics and upgrade them to the best available tech. Rare techs are fun and keep things interesting, an example is psionic tehcnology and ground troops. Policy stances are fun too, you can either fight to enslave the galaxy or emancipate it, purge Xenos or welcome them, live by the Prime Directive or bring stone-age civs to space-faring vassal states to name a few!Combat is a bit simplistic, ordering fleets into battle in systems with no tactical control. I prefer this given the games huge scope but it might be a turn-off to others. Planets upgrades are grid-based zones with populations and improvements. Once you start getting a lot of colonies you can bin them in a sector and have it automate their economics which very helpful. I think the interface and tools like sectors make managing your empire feel less daunting than other 4X games.This is a fantastic real-time strategy game that will eat your free time like the best of the turn based grand strategies!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												OK, this game is awesome.  On the surface it seems like a very simplistic iPad tap and manage game, but you have to have an imagination when you play to fully appreciate it.  You have the moral dillemnas, do you enslave a populace, or do you let them try to regulate their own political system of governance?  What about lesser lifeforms and pre-warp civilizations, what about then?  Do you let them live on their own, do you scan them and learn anthropology passivley, do you try to "uplift" them and integrate them into your own workforce, do you completely purge them from your resources, or worse yet, enslave them and send them to the mines?  That little bit won me over.  It ignites the Star Trek geek in me.  Are you the Federation, the Cardassians or are you some godlike precurser race viewed by them as gods?  Hey we're just "wormhole aliens" but if you want to see us as gods, then by all the means, add to our empire!  The combat system reminds me of a cross between Settlers and Deadlock 2.  You have the military might? send them in and a brief standoff occurs.  You win or lose.  They may send more at your borders, so be prepared to defend them.  Military is wasted inside your borders.  Lots of little popup mini-quests like pirates or heretic spawn within your borders, so have an inside fleet to deal with those.  For the most part it's the simple age-old empire building of gather resources, build militaryl, defend and build and conquer.  But what I love mosst about this game are the random events and the micromanagement.  Kind of like Civilization III, but with a sector by sector grid of battles vs. the wider spread of ships and such.  Some lets me down, some feels more fun.  It's a fun game in any sense.  What I DO wish, is that there were more victory conditions than mere expansionism and conquest.  I play this game, and I wish I could be more peaceful and mercantile.  I wish I could meet other races and form a federation.  As it stands (and I may be wrong since I just bought it a day ago) is that you build power and sieze it.  I want to be the good guy and uplift civilizations, make them my own, and I want to hash out alliances and trade empires, build more than destroy.  That's my only beef with this game, it seems too straightforward kill them all, ala Settlers 7.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												Oh manIt's three seperate research trees that you can specialize your race forIt's being able to make a race of peace loving spiders or hatefull blobs, theocratic fox people or Isolationist mushrooms, basically whatever you could hope for.It has the war justification/retalliation demands of EU4Rebels are diverse and a real threat, not because they are going to conquer you, but they soften you up, sometimes make you abolish slavery, and that sucks when your empire is primarily racist space parots.You can change your government type. You probobly wont, but you can.Sectors were pretty bad but they've gotten better (the AI component to controling your empire as it gets big)It's just great, and more is on the way. Thanks ParadoxConsHard mode can become impossible mode when the computer next to you is the "Evangalizing Zealot" type and get's an early start, but normal mode can still be a challenge.Like other Paradox grand strategy, game runs really slow in the late late game, but you can lower the game speed below normal speed if you want to watch your fleet engage the enemy and be able to see what's going on without graphical errors.Early game is exciting, mid game is dangerously thrilling, but the late game isn't as thrilling to say the least. There are some fun events that i'm not going to spoil, but at some point the game seems pretty decided. My empire of racist space parots, despite being riddled with rebel factions trying to gain footing, have a fleet that's pretty unstopable, even against the pseudo-alliance that's been made with the other nations.On that note, Federations seem less common now, Some nations just won't ally outside their accepted ethics to form a federation, even in the face of impending racist parot-related doom.Overview: 9/10 Racist Parot empire becomes the strongest nation, dosen't bother annexing the rest of space, starts a new game as a new race. Spent a lot of time in the empire creator making more nations then I'll ever play.

												This is one of my favorite games right now. The visuals are stunning and the huge map really make this game great. There's a few mechanics like the War Score system that I really don't like and the mid-game is a bit bland but I'm sure this will be fixed eventually. If it isn't, there's always mods. The only thing that I feel this game is really missing though is other victory conditions than just controlling the map. If it had something similar to Civ V where you can win in multiple different ways by focusing in different areas that could be cool, but it might take some balancing to get right. Overall this game is a solid 8/10  and with mods and the coming updates it's pretty much going to be a 10/10.

content:
Posted: March 26
												Definitely one of the best space 4X games around. It's a lot more "newbie-friendly" than a lot of other Paradox games and focuses a lot on the total cutomization of your race, its politics, and its journey, as well as lots of story-heavy elements; this is opposed to stuff like Endless Space, where the factions have a set-in-stone lore, appearance, and playstyle. It makes you feel almost like you're directing your very own space opera. Want to be a race of fanatical religious zealots who nuke every other race they come across into dust? You can do it. Want to be super friendly and found the Space UN then sing Kumbaya around a holographic fire? You can do it (although, be warned, the diplomacy system needs some TLC). Want to be Space North Korea and huddle in one corner of the galaxy and shoot anything th at comes in range? You can do that too. The main thing I enjoy about Stellaris, in order, are 1) the customization, 2) the storytelling, and 3) the roleplaying.And on top of that, it's a pretty solid, fun 4X to boot.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												I really enjoy the game from time to time. Especially if you start a new game you have a lot of stuff to do, which isn't really repetitive. Altrough after a while it becoms a bit repetitive. While I gave this game a positive review, this is not a game for everyone.Due to the sheer size of a galaxy in general, it is difficult to not create confusion and complexity in general. So here I am going to discuss some things that I think can be done better.Situation log It took me 45 hours to understand that the situation log is a very important thing. Although I have no idea how you could improve the importance of it. Maybe create another side panel at the left with important situations?A fleet manager At this point managing a fleet is really annoying, especially if you like round numbers. I would like to see some kind of manager that allows me to create a fleet, and tell me what resources, ships, etc have to be dedicated to it. At this moment everything is kinda mixed in to the right side panel, the fleet selection menu and the space station menu. This could be simplified by having 1 menu, where you select the amount of ships you want in your fleet. Upon clicking that the fleet manager should order all space stations to build these ships and order them to merge with the fleet. This should reduce the time needed to build fleets, which really make sense if you have 27 space stations that can build your ships really fast. Sector management While I really like the idea of sectors, and it sounds logic to me that the higher government only can rule about a certain amount of planets. I really would like to see the stats of the sector planets, and modify their layout at the cost of influence meaby? It doesn't make sense that the higher government can not interfere with problems on a certain planet.

												So, normally 4X games arent my thing. But this game is great. From creating your race and their political alignment, to the discovery of new star systems. Trying to uphold shaky alliances, while you wage war upon others. The game is pretty dynamic,  no 2 games of mine have been the same. The in-game events aren't that varied and the mid-game can lose one's interest a bit. But theres always something else to do - the ship designer keeps me busy! Depending on your choices for warp travel, race, policies and political alignment - you can find yourself playing a varied game each time! One down side to the game is that it will sap your time away. Start your own Sci-Fi story now!
